revision.comment: sp.: [[World Health Organization]], per [[MOS:CONSISTENCY]], proper names use the subject's own spelling (via [[WP:JWB]])
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2017}} {{Globalize|article|date=March 2018}} '''Action on Smoking and Health''' ('''ASH''') is the name of a number of autonomous [[pressure group]]s ([[charities]]) that seek to publicise the risks associated with [[tobacco smoking]] and campaign for [[Smoking ban|greater restrictions]] on cigarette and tobacco sales.[http://www.netdoctor.co.uk/erectiledysfunction/support_group/006145.htm ASH - Action on Smoking and Health] {{toc limit}} ==ASH (United States)== {{Infobox organization | name = Action on Smoking & Health | image = ASH logo.jpg | image_size = | abbreviation = ASH | motto = Global action for everyone's health | formation = | founder = Professor John Banzhaf | tax_id = | headquarters = Washington, DC, USA | location = 701 - 4th St, NW, DC | board_of_directors = Dr. Alfred Munzer (Chair), Mr. Doug Blanke, Dr. Chuck Crawford, Ms. Patricia Lambert, Ms. M.R. (Marion) Wells | key_people = Laurent Huber (Executive Director) | website = }} In the [[US]], ASH was formed in 1967 by [[John F. Banzhaf III]], and a distinguished body of physicians, attorneys and other prominent citizens who saw the need for an organization to represent nonsmokers’ rights. Over the years, ASH has taken the lead on a variety of initiatives to counter the deaths and economic burden imposed by the [[tobacco industry]]. ASH has a long history of advocacy, education and legal initiatives in the fight against tobacco. ASH has fought for health in courts, before legislative bodies and regulatory agencies, as well as international agencies such as the [[United Nations]] and the [[World Health Organization]]. ASH’s work and the work of its allies has spanned more than 40 years. Since the release of the original [[Surgeon General Report on smoking]] in January 1964, the global initiative for the prevention of tobacco-related damages has made enormous progress—and ASH has played a major role in achieving this progress. ASH’s actions have led to significant progress, including: * A [[Public Health Cigarette Smoking Act|ban on cigarette commercials]] over the airwaves in 1971; * A decision by Congress to ban [[smoking on airline flights]] in 1990; * The implementation of smoke-free legislation in a number of jurisdictions in the United States and other countries; * A 2001 executive order by President [[Bill Clinton]] prohibiting the government from promoting the sale or export of tobacco products; * Adoption and implementation of the [[WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control]] (FCTC), the first international treaty that deals exclusively with tobacco issues. {{clear}} ==ASH (United Kingdom)== {{Infobox organization | name = Action on Smoking and Health | image = Action on Smoking and Health (logo).jpg | image_size = 150px | alt = ASH - action on smoking and health | caption = | abbreviation = ASH | formation = {{start date|1971|01|20|df=y}} | founder = [[Royal College of Physicians]] | founding_location = | type = [[Pressure group]] / [[Charitable organization|Charity]] | registration_id = 262067{{EW charity|262067}} | status = | purpose = | headquarters = 67-68 Hatton Garden | location = London, UK | coords = | area_served = England | services = | products = | methods = | fields = | board_of_directors = | key_people = {{Unbulleted list | Deborah Arnott
{{smaller|(CEO)}} | Prof. John Moxham
{{smaller|(Chair)}} | [[Prince Richard, Duke of Gloucester|Duke of Gloucester]]
{{smaller|(Patron)}} }} | slogan = | mission = | website = {{URL|ash.org.uk}} }} In the [[United Kingdom]], ASH is a [[Charitable organization|registered charity]] established in 1971, that aims to eliminate the harm caused by tobacco. It works to raise awareness of the health risks of tobacco, and also campaigns for policy measures. It provides the secretariat of the [[All-Party Parliamentary Group]] on smoking and health.{{cite web|url=http://www.ash.org.uk/about-ash/all-party-parliamentary-group-on-smoking-and-health|title=All Party Parliamentary Group on Smoking and Health|author=|date=|website=ash.org.uk|publisher=|access-date=23 June 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150530010302/http://www.ash.org.uk/about-ash/all-party-parliamentary-group-on-smoking-and-health|archivedate=30 May 2015|df=dmy-all}} === History === ASH was established in 1971 by the [[Royal College of Physicians]] following the refusal of the [[UK Government]] to act on the College's demand for laws to reduce tobacco use. Former health minister, [[John Dunwoody]], became its first director. {{cite news |last=Roth |first=Andrew |date=1 February 2006 |title= John Dunwoody |url= https://www.theguardian.com/news/2006/feb/01/guardianobituaries.mainsection |newspaper=The Guardian |location= |access-date=23 June 2015}} Its present-day board of trustees reflects its continued support from the medical establishment as it is composed largely of doctors and scientists.{{cite web |url= http://ash.org.uk/about-ash/ash-board-of-trustees |title= ASH Board of Trustees |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |website=ash.org.uk |publisher= |access-date=23 June 2015}} ASH was awarded a [[World Health Organization|WHO]] [[World No Tobacco Day]] award in May 2011{{cite web | url=http://www.euro.who.int/en/what-we-do/health-topics/disease-prevention/tobacco/activities/wntd-2011-who-framework-convention-on-tobacco-control/world-no-tobacco-day-awards-2011| publisher=World Health Organization | title=World No Tobacco Day Awards 2011}} and the 2012 Luther L Terry Award for "Outstanding Organization" by the [[American Cancer Society]] in December 2011.{{cite web | url=http://www.fctc.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=634:congratulations-luther-terry-award-winners&catid=229:general-news&Itemid=233| publisher=Framework Convention Alliance | title=Congratulations to Luther Terry Award winners}} Its current Chief Executive, appointed in 2003, is Deborah Arnott. She was appointed Honorary Associate Professor in the Division of Epidemiology and Public Health University of Nottingham in 2011 and won the 2007 Alwyn Smith Prize awarded annually by the UK [[Faculty of Public Health]] to the person judged to have made the most outstanding contribution to the health of the public.{{cite web|title=Faculty prizes|url=http://www.fph.org.uk/faculty_prizes|website=fph.org.uk|publisher=[[Faculty of Public Health]]|accessdate=24 June 2015}} === Funding === ASH is a charity describing itself as a "campaigning public health charity that works to eliminate the harm caused by tobacco". Its funding for its core campaigning programme comes from the [[British Heart Foundation]] (BHF) and [[Cancer Research UK]] (CRUK). It has also received funding from the [[Department of Health (United Kingdom)|Department of Health]] under its Section 64 grant programme, which is earmarked for specific projects to further the department’s public health objectives, and cannot be used to [[lobbying|lobby]] the government.{{cite web| url=http://ash.org.uk/files/documents/ASH_808.pdf| publisher=ASH/Kingston Smith| title=2011 Accounts| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140818093254/http://ash.org.uk/files/documents/ASH_808.pdf| archivedate=18 August 2014| df=dmy-all}} === Campaigns === ASH uses funding from the BHF and CRUK to influence policy on a variety of issues including taxation and smuggling, health inequalities, harm reduction, and smoking and young people. It also works to raise awareness of the methods used by the tobacco industry to influence public health policies.{{cite web|title=Tobacco front groups & third party lobbying tactics|url=http://www.ash.org.uk/files/documents/ASH_835.pdf|website=ash.org.uk|accessdate=24 June 2015|date=January 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150421011640/http://www.ash.org.uk/files/documents/ASH_835.pdf|archivedate=21 April 2015|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|last1=Hammond|first1=Ross|last2=Rowell|first2=Andy|title=Trust us: We're the tobacco industry|url=http://www.ash.org.uk/files/documents/ASH_135.pdf|publisher=Campaign for Tobacco-Free Kids, Action on Smoking and Health|accessdate=24 June 2015|date=May 2001}} ASH coordinates the Smokefree Action Coalition (SFAC), the umbrella group for organisations working to reduce the harm caused by tobacco, which was set up to campaign for comprehensive smoke-free legislation.{{cite web|title=About Smokefree Action|url=http://www.smokefreeaction.org.uk/about.html|publisher=Smokefree Action Coalition|accessdate=24 June 2015}} In February 2006, ASH won its campaign for legislation which created comprehensive [[Smoking ban in England|smoke-free indoor workplace regulation]], introduced in England on 1 July 2007.{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/6196910.stm | title=England smoke ban to start 1 July | publisher=BBC | date=2006-12-01}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ash.org.uk/html/press/061201.html |publisher=ASH |accessdate=2006-12-01 |title=England to go smokefree on 1 July 2007: truly a time for celebration }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The smoke-free regulations included all pubs, bars and private members' clubs, as well as cafés, restaurants, and enclosed workplaces. A similar smoke-free law had already come into force in Scotland in March 2006,{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/3996587.stm | publisher=BBC | title=Scotland smoking ban to go ahead | date=2006-12-01}} and [[Northern Ireland]] and Wales followed in April 2007. Campaigning after this point focussed on the need for a new government strategy on tobacco control. In 2008, ten years after the publication of "Smoking Kills", a [[white paper]] on tobacco{{cite book|title=Smoking Kills: A White Paper on Tobacco.|date=1998|publisher=[[The Stationery Office|Stationery Office]]|location=London|isbn=9780101417723|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/260754/4177.pdf|accessdate=24 June 2015}} and the first comprehensive strategy to tackle the issue, ASH published "Beyond Smoking Kills" which provided a review of progress on the control of tobacco.{{cite web |url=http://ash.org.uk/current-policy-issues/beyond-smoking-kills |title=Beyond Smoking Kills |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |website=ash.org.uk |publisher= |access-date=23 June 2015}} The report called for a number of measures including a [[tobacco display ban]],{{cite news|last1=Boseley|first1=Sarah|title=Public health group calls for levy on tobacco firms to help fight smoking|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2015/jun/10/public-health-group-calls-for-levy-on-tobacco-firms-to-help-fight-smoking|accessdate=24 June 2015|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=10 June 2015}}{{cite news|title=Tobacco display ban extended to all shops|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-32188988|accessdate=24 June 2015|work=[[BBC News Online]]|date=6 April 2015}} prohibition of the sale of tobacco from vending machines and [[plain tobacco packaging|standardised tobacco packaging]].{{cite book|title=Beyond Smoking Kills: Protecting children, reducing inequalities|date=October 2008|publisher=Action on Smoking and Health|isbn=978-1-872428-79-6|url=http://ash.org.uk/files/documents/ASH_691.pdf|accessdate=24 June 2015}} The [[Health Act 2009]] provides for removal of [[cigarette machine|vending machines for tobacco products]] (implemented in October 2011{{cite news|title=Cigarette vending machines banned in England|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-15132529|accessdate=24 June 2015|work=[[BBC News Online]]|date=1 October 2011}}) and for the prohibition of the display of tobacco products at the point of sale in England, Wales and Northern Ireland. In March 2011, the Government committed to implement the point of sale legislation in England in large shops from April 2012 and in smaller shops from April 2015.{{cite web|title=Healthy Lives, Healthy People: A Tobacco Control Plan for England|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/213757/dh_124960.pdf|publisher=[[Government of the United Kingdom|HM Government]]|accessdate=24 June 2015|date=9 March 2011}} It also committed to a public consultation on standardised packaging in early 2012. ASH, and the SFAC, actively campaigned for the introduction of standardised packaging, which was included in the [[Children and Families Act 2014]]{{cite news|last1=Perraudin|first1=Frances|title=MPs pass legislation to introduce standardised cigarette packaging|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/mar/11/mps-pass-legislation-introduce-standardised-cigarette-packaging|accessdate=24 June 2015|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=11 March 2015}} and was passed into law in March 2015.{{cite web|title=Standardised tobacco packaging|url=http://ash.org.uk/files/documents/ASH_877.pdf|website=ash.org.uk|accessdate=24 June 2015|date=March 2015}} The charity described it as the "most important public health reform of this Parliament."{{cite news|last1=Triggle|first1=Nick|title=MPs back standardised cigarette packaging|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-31839859|accessdate=24 June 2015|work=[[BBC News Online]]|date=11 March 2015}} In 2015, ASH published "Smoking Still Kills" which called for a new government tobacco control strategy, and made a number of recommendations including an annual levy on tobacco companies to fund measures to help smokers quit and prevent youth uptake.{{cite book|title=Smoking Still Kills: Protecting children, reducing inequalities|date=June 2015|publisher=Action on Smoking and Health|isbn=978-1-872428-95-6|url=http://www.ash.org.uk/files/documents/ASH_962.pdf|accessdate=24 June 2015}} At the launch of the report, [[Department of Health (United Kingdom)|Parliamentary Under Secretary of State for Public Health]] [[Jane Ellison]] committed to a new tobacco control strategy.{{cite press release |author= |title=Smoking Still Kills: Government announced key recommendation: a new tobacco control strategy |url=http://www.ash.org.uk/media-room/press-releases/:smoking-still-kills-government-announced-key-recommendation-a-new-tobacco-control-strategy |location= |publisher=Action on Smoking and Health |agency= |date=10 June 2015 |access-date=24 June 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150613005113/http://www.ash.org.uk/media-room/press-releases/%3Asmoking-still-kills-government-announced-key-recommendation-a-new-tobacco-control-strategy |archivedate=13 June 2015 |df=dmy-all }} [[Christopher Snowdon]], a research fellow at the [[Institute of Economic Affairs]], which had received funding from tobacco firms,{{cite news|last1=Doward|first1=Jamie|title=Health groups dismayed by news 'big tobacco' funded rightwing thinktanks|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2013/jun/01/thinktanks-big-tobacco-funds-smoking|accessdate=24 June 2015|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=1 June 2013}} noted the influence of the charity saying that the "manifesto of this tiny pressure group is, in effect, the manifesto of whichever party is in power."{{cite journal |last=Snowdon |first=Christopher |author-link=Christopher Snowdon |date=1 June 2015 |title=The anti-smoking pressure group whose wackiest ideas always become law |url=http://health.spectator.co.uk/the-anti-smoking-pressure-group-whose-wackiest-ideas-always-become-law/ |journal=[[The Spectator]] |location= |publisher= |access-date=24 June 2015}} ASH is also a member of the [[World Health Organization]]'s [[Framework Convention Alliance]] on [[Tobacco Control]]. ==== Membership ==== ASH covers the whole of the UK and encourages supporters to get involved in the organisation's work, or just lend financial support. ASH Northern Ireland, ASH Scotland and ASH Wales are separate organisations. ===ASH Scotland=== ASH Scotland is an independent Scottish charity which aims to take action to reduce the harm caused by tobacco. First founded under the auspices of the [[Royal College of Physicians of Edinburgh]] in 1973, ASH Scotland became a wholly separate charity in 1993.{{cite web|title=Our history|url=http://www.ashscotland.org.uk/about-us/our-history/|website=ASH Scotland|publisher=ASH Scotland|accessdate=15 October 2015}} The organisation seeks to improve health and quality of life by limiting the number of young people taking up smoking, reducing the number of adult smokers, protecting people from second-hand smoke and tackling the inequality resulting from tobacco use. This involves campaigning for change in the law, providing information to politicians, healthcare professionals and the public, and running programmes designed to help people be tobacco-free. Following ASH Scotland campaigns, Scotland was the first part of the UK to introduce [[List of smoking bans#Scotland|smoke-free public places legislation]] and the first part of the UK (and the third country globally) to declare a tobacco-free date (2034) as part of the Scottish Government's tobacco control strategy 'Creating a tobacco-free generation'.{{cite web|title=Creating a Tobacco-free Generation|url=http://www.gov.scot/resource/0041/00417331.pdf|website=Scottish Government|publisher=Scottish Government|accessdate=15 October 2015}} ===ASH Wales=== ASH Wales is a smoking cessation and health charity that began in 1976 as an autonomous branch of ASH UK, and later granted independent charity status in 2007.{{Cite web|url = https://www.gov.uk/government/organisations/charity-commission|title = ASH Wales Limited|date = |access-date = 12 February 2016|website = Charity Commission|publisher = |last = |first = }} Its aim is to reduce the prevalence of smoking across Wales by identifying and addressing influential factors, increasing public awareness, and improving the quality and reach of cessation services.{{Cite web|url = http://ashwales.org.uk/en/about|title = About us|date = |access-date = 12 February 2016|website = ASH Wales|publisher = |last = |first = }} ASH Wales engages in a variety of projects including campaigning for tobacco-control public-health policy, research, training, educational workshops, advocacy, and support. ==== Campaigns ==== From 2012 onward ASH Wales campaigned for all 22 local authorities in Wales to introduce smoke-free policies in their children’s playgrounds. To date, 20 out of 22 local authorities have implemented voluntary bans in their local playgrounds, with another currently in the process of implementing a ban.{{Cite web|url = http://ashwales.org.uk/en/information-resources/topics/smokefree-playgrounds|title = Smoke-free playgrounds|date = |access-date = 12 February 2016|website = ASH Wales|publisher = |last = |first = }} ASH Wales played an instrumental role in the Welsh Government’s decision to enforce a ban on smoking in cars with children.{{Cite web|url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-politics-32958077|title = Smoking ban in cars carrying children passed by assembly|date = |access-date = 12 February 2016|website = BBC News|publisher = |last = |first = }} Smoking in a private vehicle when someone under the age of 18 is present became illegal in England and Wales on 1 October 2015. ==== The Filter Project ==== The Filter is the youth project of ASH Wales which delivers quit smoking support and prevention for children and young people aged 11–25.{{Cite web|title = ASH Wales Cymru|url = http://ashwales.org.uk/en/about/our-youth-project|website = ASH Wales Cymru|access-date = 2016-02-12}} The Filter provides workshops and quit smoking programmes delivered by smoking cessation advisors. The Filter Project was launched in 2013 as a result of funding from the [[Big Lottery Fund]].{{Cite web|title = Child smoking: Ash Wales given £850,000 Lottery funding to help young quit|url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-18022123|website = BBC News|access-date = 2016-02-12}} Since then The Filter has delivered its workshops and cessation support to more than 6,000 people across Wales. From 2015 The Filter became part of an Erasmus+ funded partnership bringing together organisations from 5 different EU countries with the aim of reducing tobacco consumption across all of the nations.{{Cite web|title = ASH Wales Cymru|url = http://ashwales.org.uk/en/whats-new/erasmus-comes-to-wales|website = ASH Wales Cymru|access-date = 2016-02-12}} This partnership will examine the potential of The Filter to work on a transnational basis. ==== Wales Tobacco or Health Network ==== The Wales Tobacco or Health Network (WTHN) is a professional network led by ASH Wales for individuals in Wales with an interest in tobacco and its impact on public health. It focuses on smoking and tobacco control but also on wider issues of health and well being such as the links between wealth and health inequality.{{Cite web|title = ASH Wales Cymru|url = http://ashwales.org.uk/en/get-involved/professional-networks/wales-tobacco-or-health-network|website = ASH Wales Cymru|access-date = 2016-02-12}} The network contains both individuals and organisations with members from many sectors, including academia, the tobacco control community, education, government, healthcare, local government, the media, the NHS, public health, and the private and voluntary sectors. ==== Wales Tobacco Control Alliance ==== The Wales Tobacco Control Alliance (WTCA) is a network managed by ASH Wales to enable all third sector and professional organisations involved with tackling tobacco in Wales to inform and influence policy development and implementation. The WTCA came together to campaign for a comprehensive Tobacco Control Strategy for Wales and now work to monitor this plan and reduce the harm caused by tobacco use more generally. Since 2008 over 30 organisations have joined the WTCA. This includes other charities like Cancer Research UK, the British Heart Foundation, along with professional bodies such as the Royal College of Physicians and the British Medical Association. Following a campaign by the WTCA the Welsh Government published its Tobacco Control Action Plan in February 2012 which set out a comprehensive strategy containing ambitions to reduce adult smoking prevalence to 16% by 2020.{{Cite web|title = Smoking ban: ASH calls for more legislation to cut adult rates|url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-22567778|website = BBC News|access-date = 2016-02-12}} == ASH (Australia) == {{Expand section|date=March 2018}} == ASH (New Zealand) == {{Expand section|date=March 2018}} In [[New Zealand]], ASH was formed in 1983.{{cite web|title=Action for Smokefree 2025|url=https://www.ash.org.nz/about|website=ASH (New Zealand)|accessdate=12 March 2018|language=en}} In 2011, the [[New Zealand Government]] set a target of making NZ smokefree by 2025.{{cite web|title=Smokefree 2025|url=https://www.health.govt.nz/our-work/preventative-health-wellness/tobacco-control/smokefree-2025|website=Ministry of Health (New Zealand)|accessdate=12 March 2018}} == See also == * [[Smoking in the United Kingdom]] * [[List of cigarette smoke carcinogens]] * [[Tobacco control]] * [[Philip Morris v. Uruguay]] * [[FOREST]], pro-smoking UK pressure group ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://ash.org/ ASH United States] * [http://www.ashaust.org.au/ ASH Australia] * [http://www.ash.org.nz/ ASH New Zealand] * [http://www.ashscotland.org.uk/ ASH Scotland] * [http://www.ash.org.uk/ ASH United Kingdom] * [http://www.ashwales.org.uk/ ASH Wales] * [http://www.smokefreeaction.org.uk/ Smokefree Action Coalition] {{Portal bar|Health|Social movements}} [[Category:Smoking in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Smoking in the United States]] [[Category:Tobacco control]] [[Category:Charities based in London]] [[Category:Charities based in Wales]] [[Category:Health campaigns]] [[Category:Public health organizations]] [[Category:Health charities in the United States]] [[Category:Public health in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Charities based in Scotland]] [[Category:Medical and health organizations based in Washington, D.C.]]

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Lakes of Iran]]; added [[Category:Reservoirs in Iran]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Use British English|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox company | name = Bio Products Laboratory Limited | logo = | slogan = | type = [[Limited company]] | genre = | foundation = 1954 | founder = | location_city = [[Elstree]] | location_country = United Kingdom | location = | locations = | area_served = | key_people = | industry = [[Healthcare]] | products = [[Blood plasma]] | services = | market cap = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | assets = | equity = | owner = [[Creat Group]] (100%) | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = http://www.bpl.co.uk/ | footnotes = | intl = }} The '''Bio Products Laboratory''' (BPL) is a company involved in the manufacture of human [[blood plasma]] products, located in [[Elstree]] in the [[United Kingdom]]. It is owned by the Creat Group, a Chinese investment firm.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baincapital.com/news/creat-group-corporation-agrees-acquire-bio-products-laboratory-ltd | title=Creat Group Corporation agrees to acquire Bio Products Laboratory Ltd. | publisher=Bain Capital |date=18 May 2016 |accessdate=14 April 2017}}</ref> Before August 2016, it had been owned by [[Bain Capital]] (80%) and the [[UK Government]] (20%) via holding company Plasma Resources UK Ltd. BPL is run as a commercial business and supplies plasma derived products to the [[National Health Service]] in the UK as well as to markets in 45 countries.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.bpl.co.uk/about-bpl/|title = About BPL|accessdate = 21 October 2015|publisher = Bio Products Laboratory}}{{Self-published source|date = October 2015}}</ref>
==History== The Blood Products Laboratory was established in 1954 as part of the [[Lister Institute of Preventive Medicine]] by the [[Medical Research Council (United Kingdom)|Medical Research Council]]. Lister purchased the Elstree site in 1902 and operated on the site until 1978.
During this time, Professor R. A.Kekwick, working at the Lister Institute undertook experimental and production work with A.S. McFarlane. The two scientists devised a process to clarify outdated blood plasma to render it suitable for transfusion. Laboratory testing was undertaken in the historic Queensbury Lodge, the site of Joseph Lister's laboratory.
In 1943, Kekwick was appointed Head of the Lister's Biophysics Division, Kekiwick established the Blood Filtration Unit and he and his team worked on methods of freeze-drying plasma and then of separating out proteins in blood plasma. These early products were used tomeet the needs of the Armed Services and civilian establishments. In 1948 the Blood Filtration Unit came under the joint management of the Medical Research Council (MRC) and the Lister Institute, and the name was changed to the Blood Products Research Unit and it occupied the newly built laboratories (or ‘Building 25’). The aim of the Unit was directed towards the preparation of plasma fractions for clinical use
During the 1940s, Brinkhous and McFarlane discovered that transfusions using whole blood or plasma provided a means of FVIII replacement. Applications using this early discover were limited due to naturally low concentrations of this anti-haemophilic factor in blood and plasma and volume constraints in the circulatory system.
In 1954, the Government wished to establish a site for increased production of blood products. This followed on from the importance of blood in therapeutic medicine, the need for blood products during the Second World War (particularly the use of albumin) and the formation on 26 September 1946 of the National Blood Transfusion Service. It had also been discovered that a second form of haemophilia (Haemophilia B) existed, which was treatable with blood protein called Factor IX. An agreement was reached between the Government, MRC and the Lister Institute and the Blood Products Laboratory was established with funding from the Ministry of Health. Enlarged facilities for plasma fractionation and freeze-drying were established.
During the 1970s and 1980s it became apparent that Factor VIII products produced at the BPL site (and other products from other companies) had infected haemophiliacs with life-threatening viruses.<ref>{{cite web|title=Final Report: Chapter 19 - Production of Blood Products - Facilities|url=http://www.penroseinquiry.org.uk/finalreport/text/354876_chapter_19.html|website=www.penroseinquiry.org.uk|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Wheeler|first1=Caroline|title=Sick children infected with HIV and used as guinea pigs as NHS said chimps 'too expensive'|url=https://www.express.co.uk/news/uk/600114/Children-were-cheap-guinea-pigs-deadly-tainted-blood-products|website=Express.co.uk|language=en|date=23 August 2015}}</ref>
In 1991 it was renamed the Bio Products Laboratory to reflect the internal market in the National Health Service and in 1993 it became part of the [[National Blood Authority]]. BPL began cross-charging NHS hospitals for its products and limited competition in the international blood plasma market was permitted.
In 1998 the BPL began sourcing its plasma from the [[United States]] due to concerns over [[vCJD]] in the UK. In 2002 the [[Department of Health (United Kingdom)|Department of Health]] (DoH) formed [[DCI Biologicals Inc]] to purchase US company [[Life Resources Inc]] to supply all of the BPL's plasma.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/health/2582389.stm|title = UK buys 'safe' blood supply for NHS|publisher = BBC News|date = 17 December 2002|work = BBC News World Edition|access-date = 21 October 2015|last = Staff}}</ref>
BPL became an operating division within new [[Special Health Authority]], [[NHS Blood and Transplant]], in 2005. This placed BPL alongside the National Blood Service and the organ transplant division, a strategic partnership to safeguard blood, tissues and blood products.
On 31 December 2010 the BPL was vested into a limited company, Bio Products Laboratory Ltd, and ownership transferred to the DoH, with BPL Ltd and DCI Biologicals Inc brought under the same DoH holding company, Plasma Resources UK Ltd.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.bpl.co.uk/about-bpl/news/q/date/2011/01/05/transfer-of-bio-products-laboratory-to-limited-co/|title = Transfer of Bio Products Laboratory to Limited Co|publisher = Bio Products Laboratory|date = 5 January 2011|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110808131625/http://www.bpl.co.uk/about-bpl/news/q/date/2011/01/05/transfer-of-bio-products-laboratory-to-limited-co/|archive-date=8 August 2011 }}{{Self-published source|date = October 2015}}</ref>
On 18 July 2013 it was announced by Business Secretary Vince Cable that [[Bain Capital]] had bought 80% of Plasma Resources UK (PRUK) from the DoH for £230m, which included both BPL and DCI Biologicals. The company was subsequently renamed BPL Holdings, with the original BPL site now called BPL Therapeutics and DCI named BPL Plasma. In July 2016, Bain Capital sold BPL Holdings to Creat, a Chinese-based investment company who part own a Chinese plasma fractionator. In 2018, Creat announced plans to integrate BPL with the German plasma products manufacturer Biotest.
==See also== * [[National Blood Service]] * [[NHS Blood and Transplant]] * Sandle, T. (2004). [https://www.scribd.com/doc/45638268/BPL50YearBrochure A Brief History of Bio Products Laboratory and the Elstree Site].
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.bpl.co.uk// Bio Products Laboratory website] * [https://bplplasma.com BPL's US website] * Tim Sandle's history of BPL 1954-2004 [https://www.scribd.com/doc/75974837/BPL-History] * History of Bio Products Laboratory at 60 (1954 - 2014) [http://www.pharmamicroresources.com/2015/03/bio-products-laboratory-at-60.html]
[[Category:Department of Health (United Kingdom)]]

{{Infobox organization | name = British HIV Association | abbreviation = BHIVA | established = 1995 | location = [[United Kingdom]] | leader_title = Chair | leader_name = Prof. Chloe Orkin | website=[http://www.bhiva.org Official website] }}
The '''British HIV Association''' ('''BHIVA''') is an organisation of healthcare professionals interested in the treatment and care of people with [[HIV]].
The current BHIVA Chair is Professor Chloe Orkin.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ukcab.net/forum/index.php?topic=3253.0|title=UK CAB minutes|last=UK CAB|first=|date=|website=www.ukcab.net|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=12 September 2017}}</ref>
The aims of BHIVA are, to advance: * Promotion of good practice in the treatment of HIV
* Public education through the promotion and dissemination of research<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.kingsfund.org.uk/sites/default/files/media/Chloe%20Orkin-presentation.pdf|title=Kings Fund Concluding Remarks|last=Orkin|first=Chloe|date=|website=www.kingsfund.org.uk|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=12 September 2017}}</ref>
==Conferences== BHIVA holds two national conferences per year, the BHIVA National Conference in April and the BHIVA Autumn Conference.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://i-base.info/htb/24714|title=i-base Future Meetings|last=i-base|first=|date=12 September 2017|website=i-base|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
==Guidelines== BHIVA produce guidelines which are accredited by the UK [[National Institute for Health and Care Excellence]] (NICE).<ref>{{Cite website|title=NICE Accreditation Decisions|last=NICE|first=|date=12 September 2017|url=https://www.nice.org.uk/About/What-we-do/Accreditation/Accreditation-decisions|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== See also == * [[HIV/AIDS in the United Kingdom]]
==References== <references />
[[Category:HIV/AIDS in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:AIDS activism]] [[Category:Medical associations based in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:HIV/AIDS organizations]]

{{Refimprove|date=February 2017}} {{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = Bullous keratopathy | synonyms = | image = Cornea.png | caption = Bullous keratopathy is a condition that occurs in the cornea | pronounce = | field = | symptoms = | complications = | onset = | duration = | types = | causes = | risks = | diagnosis = | differential = | prevention = | treatment = | medication = | prognosis = | frequency = | deaths = }} '''Bullous keratopathy''' is a pathological condition in which small vesicles, or ''[[Bulla (dermatology)|bullae]]'', are formed in the [[cornea]] due to [[corneal endothelium|endothelial]] dysfunction.
In a healthy cornea, endothelial cells keeps the tissue from excess fluid absorption, pumping it back into the aqueous humor. When affected by some reason, such as [[Fuchs' dystrophy]] or a trauma during cataract removal, endothelial cells suffer mortality or damage.<ref name="Stuart">{{cite journal |author=Stuart AJ, Virgili G, Shortt AJ |title= Descemet's membrane endothelial keratoplasty versus Descemet's stripping automated endothelial keratoplasty for corneal endothelial failure |journal=Cochrane Database Syst Rev|volume= |issue=3|pages= CD012097 |date=2016 |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/14651858.CD012097/pdf |doi= 10.1002/14651858.CD012097}}</ref> The corneal endothelial cells normally do not undergo mitotic cell division, and cell loss results in permanent loss of function. When endothelial cell counts drop too low, the pump starts failing to function and fluid moves anterior into the stroma and epithelium. The excess fluid precipitates swelling of the cornea. As fluid accumulates between the basal epithelium cells, blister like formations form (bullae) and they undergo painful ruptures releasing their fluid content to the surface. These characteristic malformations disrupt vision and create pain sensations.
==Symptoms== Disease begins with vesicles that coalesce. There is severe progressing edema and rupture may occur in 24 hours or less.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eyevet.ca/bullous.html|title=Eye Vet - Zigler Veterinary Professional Corporation|website=Eyevet.ca|accessdate=9 July 2018}}</ref> Bullous keratopathy ==Treatment==
Treatment can include hyperosmotic eye drops to reduce swelling (5% sodium chloride), bandage contact lenses to reduce discomfort, glaucoma medications to reduce the flow of fluid into the cornea, and surgical procedures to replace the damaged tissue. The most common types of surgical treatment are Descemet's stripping automated endothelial keratoplasty (DSAEK) and Descemet's membrane endothelial keratoplasty (DMEK).<ref name="Stuart"/>
==Prognosis== Keratopathy is common in older people. Keratopathy occurs after cataract surgery, its incidence has decreased since the advent of intraoperative viscoelastic agents that protect the endothelium.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.missionforvisionusa.org/anatomy/2005/11/bullous-keratopathy-of-cornea.html|title=Ocular Pathology: Bullous Keratopathy of the Cornea|website=Missionforvisionusa.org|accessdate=9 July 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Medical resources | DiseasesDB = 32601 | ICD10 = H18.1 | ICD9 = {{ICD9|371.23}} | ICDO = | OMIM = | MedlinePlus = | eMedicineSubj = | eMedicineTopic = | MeshID = }}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bullous Keratopathy}} [[Category:Diseases of the eye and adnexa]]

revision.text:
'''Capital punishment in Sudan''' is legal under Article 27 of the Sudanese Criminal Act 1991.<ref>International Committee of the Red Cross. 1991 Criminal Act https://www.icrc.org/applic/ihl/ihl-nat.nsf/0/4d8b568d3792381cc12571100038b7d0/$FILE/Criminal%20Act%20-%20Sudan%20-%20EN.pdf.</ref> The Act is based on [[Sharia law]] which prescribes both the death penalty and corporal punishment, such as amputation.<ref>http://www.handsoffcain.info/bancadati/schedastato.php?idcontinente=25&nome=sudan</ref> [[Sudan]] has moderate execution rates, ranking [[Use of capital punishment by country|8th overall]] in 2014 when compared to other countries that still continue the practice, after at least 29 executions were reported (although it is expected that over 100 occurred).<ref>Amnesty International Report on Death Sentences and Executions 2013 at p 10</ref>
==History== Even though Sudan's legal systems have been drawn from various other jurisdictions, [[capital punishment]] has always existed in the country.<ref>Inter Press Service. Death Penalty: Sudan Still Sentencing Minors to Death per Hamed Emam. http://www.ipsnews.net/2010/11/death-penalty-sudan-still-sentencing-minors-to-death/</ref>
During the last 100 years there have been a number of changes to Sudanese law. In the early 1900s until 1974 the death penalty was active in a legal system based on Indian criminal law, which in itself was influenced by Anglo-Saxon law.<ref>African Centre for Justice and Peace Studies. Widening the Scope: The Expanding Use of Capital Punishment in Law and Practice in Sudan. December 2010 at p 2</ref> In 1974, during President [[Gaafar Nimeiry| Gaafar Nimeiry's]] time in office, large scale amendments to the penal code were carried out which included some elements of civil law. However, the civil law amendments were never integrated into the Sudanese penal code which caused a number limitations for the courts.<ref>African Centre for Justice and Peace Studies. Widening the Scope: The Expanding Use of Capital Punishment in Law and Practice in Sudan. December 2010 at p 2</ref> After this failure the previous Indian influenced penal law was reinstated. The basis of the legal system continued its yoyo pattern when in 1983 the Nimeiry regime sought to promote the [[Muslim Brotherhood|Muslim Brotherhood's]] version of Sharia law. Nimeiry's office revised a number of national laws to reflect this, including the penal code, only to have it repealed two years later and the 1974 criminal code restored once more.<ref>African Centre for Justice and Peace Studies. Widening the Scope: The Expanding Use of Capital Punishment in Law and Practice in Sudan. December 2010 at p 3</ref> In 1991 the 1974 penal code was replaced for a second time by the 1991 Criminal Code which is still in use today. By this time President [[Omar Al-Bashir]] had come to power after a 1989 coup, led by the fundamentalist [[National Islamic Front]] (NIF).<ref>US Department of State, Country Report on Human Rights Practices, Sudan. http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2004/41628.htm</ref> The reformations made by the Al-Bashir government helped to promote Islamisation in the country.
Though the identifier "criminal code" was chosen over "penal code" due to the fact the new laws included provisions which would promote care and rehabilitation, the government had no plans to follow growing international opinion against the death penalty and, to the contrary, further entrenched the practice. Rather than begin to draw back, the scope of the application of the penalty has expanded since the introduction of the code. In the most recent periodic report of the government of Sudan to the African Commission on Human and Peoples' Rights it states that Sudan sees no reason to abolish the death sentence.<ref>The 4th and 5th Periodic Reports of the Republic of the Sudan in Accordance with Article 62 of the African Charter on Human and Peoples Rights 2008 – 2012. http://www.achpr.org/files/sessions/51st/state-reports/4thand5th-2008-2012/staterep4and5_sudan_2012_eng.pdf</ref>
==Legislation==
===Crimes that attract capital punishment=== * Crimes against the state such as espionage, instigation of war against the state and undermining constitutional order.<ref>1991 Criminal Act, chapter 5, art 50-53.</ref> * Religious crimes. Muslims are prohibited from changing their religion ([[apostasy]]). * Crimes against body and soul. This includes murder and the instigation of a minor to commit suicide.<ref>1991 Criminal Act, chapter 14, art 130, 134.</ref> *Crimes of honour, public morality and reputation. This includes; [[adultery]] (which is punishable by [[stoning]]),<ref>1991 Criminal Act, chapter 15, art 146(1)(a).</ref> [[sodomy]],<ref>1991 Criminal Act, chapter 15, art 148(2)(c)</ref> rape if it also constitutes adultery or sodomy,<ref>1991 Criminal Act, chapter 15, art 149(3)</ref> incest<ref>1991 Criminal Act, chapter 15, art 150</ref> and prostitution.<ref>1991 Criminal Act, chapter 15, art 155(3)</ref>
Article (27)(1) of the 1991 Act states that:
''execution is either by hanging or stoning or in the same manner as the commitment of murder by the perpetrator, and may be as a [[hudud]] punishment or in retribution or approximation, and may be with crucifixion ''
Generally, however, the punishment is executed by hanging.<ref>African Centre for Justice and Peace. Widening the Scope: The Expanding Use of Capital Punishment in Law and Practice in Sudan. December 2010 at p 15</ref>
==Capital punishment in practice==
===Procedural guarantees=== For a person charged with a capital crime in Sudan there are a number of procedural guarantees they should receive: *Innocent until proven guilty *The person charged with the offence should not be forced to self incriminate or be made to take any oaths except under limited circumstances. *There is a right to appeal *The person charged has the right to medical care, to be safe from harm and to be able to contact a lawyer and their family *Bail. However Article 106 (1) states that "the detained for crimes punishable with the death penalty or an amputation shall not be released".
These guarantees are only available at trial stage meaning that during the investigation period individuals may be dangerously exposed, particularly because torture (though illegal under Sudanese law) has been documented on numerous occasions.<ref>African Centre for Justice and Peace Studies, Widening the Scope: The Expanding Use of Capital Punishment and Law in Sudan, December 2010 at p 15.</ref>
==Cases== The following cases demonstrate the kinds of actions that have led to recent episodes of capital punishment in the country. Although Sudan is a signatory to the [[Convention on the Rights of the Child|U.N Convention on the Rights of the Child]][http://www.ohchr.org/en/professionalinterest/pages/crc.aspx] until an amendment made in 2010, Sudan was still one of the few remaining countries whose death penalty extended to juveniles. One of the last juveniles to be killed by death penalty was Abdulrahman Zakaria Mohammed in May 2009. He had been found guilty of murder and robbery. The decision was decided based on two factors, as confirmed by the UN Special Rapporteur on independence of judges and lawyers; firstly, the prohibition of the death penalty for children did not extend to [[hudud]] offences, and secondly the Court believed that because the definition of 'adult' in the Criminal Act was "any person whose puberty has been established by definite natural features and who has completed 15 years of age and whoever obtains 18 years of age shall be deemed an adult even if the features of puberty do not exist". Using this definition of adult, the Court determined that Abdulrahman could be treated as an adult, even though he was only 17 at the time he was arrested. Also in 2009, four children between the ages of 15 to 17 were sentenced to death after being found guilty of armed robbery. In 2007 two young women in their early 20s were sentenced to death by stoning for committing adultery under Article 146 (a) of the Criminal Act. The woman did not have legal representation nor assistance to help defend themselves.<ref>African Centre for Justice and Peace Studies, Widening the Scope: The Expanding Use of Capital Punishment and Law in Sudan, December 2010 at p 3</ref>
==Criticism== Criticism of capital punishment in Sudan usually centers on two rights protections: the protection to the right to life and the protection against cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. These rights are both recognized in the [[Universal Declaration of Human Rights]] and the [[African Charter on Human and Peoples Rights]].
There are a number of human rights violations that occur because of Sudanese law. For example, Article 126 (2) of the 1991 Criminal Act, which stipulates religious crimes that may result in capital sentencing, is a violation of the right to freedom of conscience and religious creed.
Also, though the procedural guarantees are consistent with international standards, they are limited in practice and the lack of access to bail is evidence of this. Sima Samar, the [[United Nations special rapporteur|Special Rapporteur]] for Human Rights in Sudan has noted in the past that the lack of sufficient guarantees of a fair trial for the accused facing the death penalty demonstrates serious doubts about compliance.<ref>Report of the Special Rapporteur on the human rights situation in Sudan, Sima Samar to the Commission on Human Rights, E/CN.4/2006/111, 11 January 2006 at para 54.</ref>
==See also== *[[Sudan]] *[[Use of capital punishment by country]] *[[Human rights in Sudan]]
==References== {{reflist}} {{capital punishment}} {{Africa topic|Capital punishment in}}
[[Category:Capital punishment by country|Sudan]] [[Category:Penal system in Sudan]] [[Category:Human rights in Sudan]]

revision.comment: Hatnote because I confused these terms today
revision.text:
{{distinguish|Cataplexy}} {{For|the band|Catalepsy (band)}} {{Redirect|Cataleptic|the poetry term|catalectic}} {{Infobox medical condition | Name = Catalepsy | Image = Catalepsys boy.jpg | Caption = | DiseasesDB = | ICD10 = {{ICD10|F|20|2|f|20}}, {{ICD10|F|44|2|f|40}} | ICD9 = {{ICD9|295.2}}, {{ICD9|300.11}} | ICDO = | OMIM = | MedlinePlus = | eMedicineSubj = | eMedicineTopic = | MeshID = D002375 }} '''Catalepsy''' (from [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] κατάληψις "seizing, grasping") is a nervous condition characterized by [[muscle|muscular]] rigidity and fixity of [[human position|posture]] regardless of external stimuli, as well as decreased sensitivity to [[pain]].<ref>http://www.medterms.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=11104</ref>
==Signs and symptoms== [[File:Female patient with melancolie catalepsy Wellcome L0040298 (cropped).jpg|thumb|Female with depression and catalepsy]] [[File:Rigidity of the body produced by catalepsy.jpg|thumb|Rigidity of the body produced by catalepsy]] Symptoms include: rigid body, rigid limbs, limbs staying in same position when moved ([[waxy flexibility]]), no response, loss of muscle control, and slowing down of bodily functions, such as breathing.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1037/0735-7044.102.5.748 |vauthors=Sanberg PR, Bunsey MD, Giordano M, Norman AB |title=The catalepsy test: its ups and downs |journal=Behav. Neurosci. |volume=102 |issue=5 |pages=748–59 |date=October 1988 |pmid=2904271 |url=http://content.apa.org/pubmed/bne/102/5/748}}</ref>
==Causes== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Catalepsie catalepsy hypnosis 1941.jpg|right|thumb|400px|Subject in the rigid throes of a cataleptic attack, forming an arc with her body. {{puic|1=Catalepsie catalepsy hypnosis 1941.jpg|log=2009 July 13}}]] --> Catalepsy is a symptom of certain nervous disorders or conditions such as [[Parkinson's disease]] and [[epilepsy]]. It is also a characteristic symptom of [[cocaine]] withdrawal, as well as one of the features of catatonia.{{Citation needed|date=January 2017}} It can be caused by [[schizophrenia]] treatment with [[anti-psychotics]],<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Rasmussen K, Hsu MA, Noone S, Johnson BG, Thompson LK, Hemrick-Luecke SK |title=The orexin-1 antagonist SB-334867 blocks antipsychotic treatment emergent catalepsy: implications for the treatment of extrapyramidal symptoms |journal=Schizophr Bull |volume=33 |issue=6 |pages=1291–7 |date=November 2007 |pmid=17660489 |doi=10.1093/schbul/sbm087 |url=http://schizophreniabulletin.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=17660489 |pmc=2779883}}</ref> such as [[haloperidol]],<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Hattori K, Uchino S, Isosaka T |title=Fyn is required for haloperidol-induced catalepsy in mice |journal=J. Biol. Chem. |volume=281 |issue=11 |pages=7129–35 |date=March 2006 |pmid=16407246 |doi=10.1074/jbc.M511608200 |url=http://www.jbc.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=16407246|display-authors=etal}}</ref> and by the anesthetic [[ketamine]].<ref name="miller">{{cite book | last = Miller | first = Ronald | title = Miller's Anesthesia | publisher = Elsevier/Churchill Livingstone | location = New York | year = 2005 | isbn = 0-443-06656-6 }}</ref> [[Protein kinase A]] has been suggested as a mediator of cataleptic behavior.<ref name="pmid9342379">{{cite journal |vauthors=Adams MR, Brandon EP, Chartoff EH, Idzerda RL, Dorsa DM, McKnight GS |title=Loss of haloperidol induced gene expression and catalepsy in protein kinase A-deficient mice |journal=Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. |volume=94 |issue=22 |pages=12157–61 |date=October 1997 |pmid=9342379 |pmc=23735 |doi=10.1073/pnas.94.22.12157 |url=http://www.pnas.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=9342379}}</ref>
==Historical cases== [[St. Teresa of Avila]] experienced a prolonged bout of catalepsy that began in 1539. This episode was precipitated by the stress she was suffering at the Carmelite Convent of the Incarnation. Her legs became rigid, leaving her an invalid for three years. Teresa endured intermittent attacks of catalepsy from then on.<ref>St. Teresa of Avila, ''The Life of St. Teresa de Avila, 1565, chapters V, VI, and VII.''</ref>
==Artistic depictions== In the arts, catalepsy is often used for [[drama]]tic effect, sometimes as a [[plot device]].
===In literature=== In [[Alexandre Dumas, père]]'s novel ''[[The Count of Monte Cristo]]'', the Abbé Faria has fits of catalepsy from time to time, before eventually dying from one.
In [[Eugène Sue]]'s ''[[The Mysteries of Paris]]'', the villain Jacques Ferrand experiences a fit described as cataleptic in his final confrontation with Rodolphe, blinded by lamplight and hallucinating with visions of his fantasized Cecily.
In [[George Eliot]]'s ''[[Silas Marner]]'', the main character Silas Marner frequently has cataleptic fits and seizures. It is not mentioned if they are caused by any of the aforementioned factors.
In [[Arthur Conan Doyle]]'s "[[The Adventure of the Resident Patient]]", a man feigns catalepsy to gain access to a neurologist's rooms; the doctor attempts to treat him with [[amyl nitrite]].
In [[Ford Madox Ford]]'s ''[[The Good Soldier]]'', the protagonist Dowell experiences catalepsy following the death of his wife.
In [[Robert A. Heinlein]]'s ''[[Stranger in a Strange Land]]'', the main character Valentine Michael Smith is believed to have catalepsy when he is returned to Earth.
In [[Edgar Allan Poe]]'s "[[The Premature Burial]]", the narrator develops catalepsy. He fears being mistakenly declared dead and buried alive, and goes to great lengths to prevent this. In another of Poe's short stories, "[[The Fall of the House of Usher]]", Madeline Usher has catalepsy, and is buried alive by her unstable brother Roderick. Catalepsy is also depicted in "[[Berenice (short story)|Berenice]]", thus becoming one of the recurrent themes in Poe's fiction.
In [[Poppy Z. Brite]]'s ''[[Exquisite Corpse (novel)|Exquisite Corpse]]'', the main character—Comptom, a serial killer (recreation of [[Jeffery Dahmer]]'s life story) facing a lifetime sentence—uses shamanistic techniques to induce catalepsy, and, convincingly appearing deceased, is able to escape prison.
In [[Émile Zola]]'s short story "[[La Mort d'Olivier Becaille]]" ("The Death of Olivier Becaille"), the title character is buried alive and notes that "I must have fallen into one of those cataleptic states that I had read of".
In [[Sax Rohmer]]'s [[Fu Manchu]] novels, Dr. Fu-Manchu has a serum that induces a state of catalepsy so extreme as to be indistinguishable from death.
In [[Charles Dickens]]'s novel ''[[Bleak House]]'', Mrs. Snagsby has violent spasms before becoming cataleptic and being carried upstairs like a grand piano.
In [[Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel|Hegel]]'s ''Lectures on the History of Philosophy: Greek Philosophy to Plato'', Hegel describes [[Socrates]] as having catalepsy caused by [[magnetic somnambulism]] when in deep meditation.
In [[Charles Williams (British writer)|Charles Williams]]'s novel ''[[Many Dimensions]]'', Sir Giles Tumulty says to Lord Arglay, the Chief Justice of England: "You are a louse-brained catalept, Arglay."
In [[Philip K. Dick]]'s novel ''[[Now Wait for Last Year]]'', Kathy Sweetscent becomes immobilized by withdrawal from JJ-180, an alien (and highly addictive) drug. "My God, Kathy thought as she stood gazing down at the record by her feet. I can't free myself; I'm going to remain here, and they'll find me like this and know something's terribly wrong. This is catalepsy!"
In the second chapter of [[Álvares de Azevedo]]'s ''[[Noite na Taverna]]'', character Solfieri rescues a woman who has catalepsy from inside a coffin.
===In film and television===
In [[Sam Taylor (director)|Sam Taylor]]'s ''[[Kiki (1931 film)|Kiki]]'' (1931), [[Mary Pickford]] feigns a case of catalepsy to keep from being removed from the apartment of the man she secretly loves.
In the soap opera ''[[La Traición]]'', the main character, Hugo De Medina, has catalepsy. Later in the telenovela, it is revealed that his daughter, Aurora, has the same illness.
In ''[[Chavo del Ocho]]'', the main character, El Chavo, would have cataleptic-like seizures if frightened, where he would curl as if sitting down in a chair and become stiff. However, he could be healed by being splashed with water.
In the 1965 [[Roman Polanski]] film ''[[Repulsion (film)|Repulsion]]'', [[Catherine Deneuve]]'s character shows signs of the condition through her erratic and unexplainable behavior.
In two ''[[Star Trek: Deep Space Nine]]'' episodes, "[[Statistical Probabilities]]" and "[[Chrysalis (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Chrysalis]]", the character Sarina Douglas, a genetically-enhanced human woman, exhibits cataleptic symptoms. In "Chrysalis", [[Julian Bashir|Dr. Bashir]] promises to do everything he can to cure her of the disorder, and is ultimately successful.
In ''[[The Premature Burial (film)]]'' based on the short story by [[Edgar Allan Poe]], the protagonist is buried alive during a cataleptic episode, as his lack of response to external stimuli causes his family and doctors to believe him to be dead.
In ''[[The Fisher King]]'' (1991), [[Robin Williams]]' character Parry has this condition after witnessing the brutal murder of his wife.
In ''[[Isle of the Dead (film)|Isle of the Dead]]'' (1945), Katherine Emery's character suffers from a multitude of illness' that render her almost incapable of caring for herself. Of these many illness' she is subject to catatonic trances which inevitably lead to her demise.
In a second-season episode ("Halloween" - 1993) of [[Dr. Quinn, Medicine Woman|Doctor Quinn, Medicine Woman]], several residents of the town believe they have seen a dead man, only to have him disappear before they return with Dr. Quinn, who thinks they are playing Halloween pranks on her. Dr Quinn eventually sees the man have a seizure and diagnoses him with catalepsy.
==See also== *[[Catatonia]] *[[Mood disorder#Depressive disorders]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Mental and behavioral disorders}}
[[Category:Mental and behavioural disorders]] [[Category:Schizophrenia]]

'''Charles Basch''' is the Richard March Hoe Professor of Health and Education at [[Teachers College, Columbia University]], [[New York City, New York]]. He teaches courses related to epidemiology, planning and evaluation. Before coming to Teachers College, he was Assistant Professor of Community Health Education at [[Russell Sage College]] in [[Troy, New York]].
He earned his B.S. and M.S. in community health education at the [[State University of New York at Brockport]] and his Ph.D. in health education at [[Southern Illinois University Carbondale]], where he studied under four of the field's most prominent leaders, [[Robert S. Gold]], [[David F. Duncan]], [[Elena Sliepcevich]], and [[Robert Russell (health education)|Robert Russell]].
Basch's main scholarly interests are improving understanding of (1) health-related decision making, (2) dissemination and implementation of effective health-related programs and policies, and (3) the influence of health factors on educational outcomes in urban minority youth. In particular, he has documented a link between childhood health and learning in school. His research identifies seven factors (poor vision, asthma, teen pregnancy, aggression and violence, physical inactivity, ADHD, and insufficient breakfast) that can and do lead to health disparities and contribute to poorer academic achievement. He notes that students will perform and learn better every day if they are "well-rested and well-nourished". During his 25 years at Teachers College, he has directed approximately $15 million of grant-funded research and program development (primarily supported by the [[National Institutes of Health]]), and he continues to do so. His work has yielded over 100 scholarly publications.
==References==
* Basch, C. E., & Duncan, D. F. (1985). Promoting high level wellness in a rural state: The wellness education workshop. Health Values, 9(4), 18-23. * Basch, C.E. (2010). Healthier Students Are Better Learners: A Missing Link in Efforts to Close the Achievement Gap. Equity Matters: Research Review No. 6. New York: The Campaign for Educational Equity. * Basch, C.E. (2011). Healthier students are better learners: a missing link in school reforms to close the achievement gap. Journal of School Health, 81(10), 593-598. * Blonska, J. (March 31, 2011). Spotlight on Charles E. Basch: Healthier Students Are Better Learners. Healthy Schools Campaign, http://www.healthyschoolscampaign.org/blog/spotlight-on-charles-e-basch-healthier-students-are-better-learners * Wethington, C. (Nov. 12, 2013). Closing the achievement gap: a new vision for making it happen. MinnPost, Community Voices http://www.minnpost.com/community-voices/2013/11/closing-achievement-gap-new-vision-making-it-happen
==External links== *http://www.tc.columbia.edu/hbs/HealthEd/index.asp?Id=Faculty&Info=Charles+Basch%2C+Ph.D.

[[File:Tahril-neonatal.jpg|right|thumb|El Tahril el Aam (General Liberation Hospital), [[Basrah]]]]
'''Childbirth in Iraq''' is marked by a fertility rate of 4.0 births per woman, a contested but high maternal mortality rate and a moderately high infant mortality rate.
==Fertility rate== In 2015 Iraq's fertility rate was reported by the [[World Health Organization]] at 4.0 births per woman.<ref>Iraq: WHO Statistical Profile. (January, 2015). Global Health Observatory. Retrieved on March 21st, 2015 at http://www.who.int/gho/countries/irq.pdf?ua=1</ref>
==Mortality== ===Maternal mortality=== Maternal mortality is a much debated figure in Iraq. In 2010 the [[CIA World Factbook]] reported maternal mortality at 63 deaths/100,000 births.<ref>Middle East: Iraq. (2014, June 22). CIA World Factbook. Retrieved March 24, 2015, from https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/iz.html</ref> Iraq's Ministry of Health and the WHO reported in 2011 the maternal mortality rate at 84 death per 100,000 births. That would categorize Iraq as one of the 68 countries that account for 97% of the maternal and child deaths globally.<ref>Webster, P. C. (2013). Roots of Iraq's maternal and child health crisis run deep. The Lancet, 381(9870), 891-894.DOI: 10.1016/S0140-6736(13)60658-3</ref> In 2013 the two organizations were divided on the issue with the WHO reporting maternal mortality at 64 deaths per 100,000 and Ministry of Health reporting 25.<ref>Al Hilfi, T. K., Lafta, R., & Burnham, G. (2013). Health services in Iraq. The Lancet, 381(9870), 939-948. DOI: 10.1016/S0140-6736(13)60320-7</ref>
===Infant mortality=== In 2014 total infant mortality in Iraq was reported 37.53 deaths/1,000 live births: male: 41.57 deaths/1,000 live births and female: 33.28 deaths/1,000 live births.<ref>Middle East: Iraq. (2014, June 22). CIA World Factbook. Retrieved March 24, 2015, from https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/iz.html</ref>
==Contraceptive use == In 2013, the World Health Organization reported the contraception use rate at 53% for the population of Iraq, up from 32.9% in 2010.<ref>Iraq: Country statistics summary. (2013). World Health Organization. Retrieved on March 24, 2015 at http://rho.emro.who.int/rhodata/node.country.country-IRQ-stats?lang=en </ref>
===Abortion=== In 2009, the United Nations reported that in Iraq abortion was only permitted to preserve a women’s life. It was not allowed in the case of rape or incest, to preserve a women’s physical or mental health, for economic or social reasons, or on request.<ref>World Abortion Policies 2011. (March, 2011). United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs. Retrieved on March 24, 2015 at http://www.un.org/esa/population/publications/2011abortion/2011wallchart.pdf</ref>
==Pregnancy care providers== There are three types of pregnancy care providers in Iraq; midwives, obstetricians, and traditional birth attendants.<ref>Reed, L. (2007). Midwifery, Freedom to Practice?. Churchill Livingston, Elsevier</ref> Midwives practice in hospitals and in their home or the home of their client.<ref>Reed, L. (2007). Midwifery, Freedom to Practice?. Churchill Livingston, Elsevier</ref> They are educated in hospital based programs, but there is interest in expanding midwifery education to the university level.<ref>Reed, L. (2007). Midwifery, Freedom to Practice?. Churchill Livingston, Elsevier</ref> Once licensed, a midwife receives a plaque with her license number that she displays outside the door of her home.<ref>Reed, L. (2007). Midwifery, Freedom to Practice?. Churchill Livingston, Elsevier</ref> This lets potential clients know that she has the appropriate credentials.<ref>Reed, L. (2007). Midwifery, Freedom to Practice?. Churchill Livingston, Elsevier</ref> Midwives do not have prescribing privileges but may obtain certain medications from a physician if they are working outside of a hospital.<ref>Reed, L. (2007). Midwifery, Freedom to Practice?. Churchill Livingston, Elsevier</ref> Obstetricians are university educated and work in hospitals.<ref>Reed, L. (2007). Midwifery, Freedom to Practice?. Churchill Livingston, Elsevier</ref> Traditional birth attendants work only in clients homes <ref>Reed, L. (2007). Midwifery, Freedom to Practice?. Churchill Livingston, Elsevier</ref>
==Prenatal care== In 2006: 84% of women{{where|date=May 2015}} had at least one prenatal visit with skilled personnel. Of the women who received antenatal care: 63% had a urine sample, 66% had a blood test, and 76% had their blood pressure taken. A client's weight was taken less than the other measurements.<ref>Iraq: Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2006. (2007). Central Organization for Statistics & Information Technology. Kurdistan Regional Statistics Office. Iraq Ministry of Health. Retrieved at http://www.childinfo.org/files/MICS3_Iraq_FinalReport_2006_eng.pdf</ref>
==Labor and birth== ===Location=== In 2011, 74% of recorded births in Iraq took place in a hospital or birth center, 79% of urban births and 67% of rural births.<ref>Iraq Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2011 (2012) Retrieved at http://www.childinfo.org/files/MICS4_Iraq_PreliminaryReport_Eng.pdf</ref>
===Attendants and support persons=== In 2011, 89% of births in Iraq were attended by a skilled birth attendant.<ref>Iraq Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2011 (2012) Retrieved at http://www.childinfo.org/files/MICS4_Iraq_PreliminaryReport_Eng.pdf</ref> Sixty percent were attended by a public or private doctor and 28% were attended by a nurse-midwife or certified midwife.<ref>Iraq Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2011 (2012) Retrieved at http://www.childinfo.org/files/MICS4_Iraq_PreliminaryReport_Eng.pdf</ref> Traditional birth attendants, called jiddas, attended 10% of the births.<ref>Iraq Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2011 (2012) Retrieved at http://www.childinfo.org/files/MICS4_Iraq_PreliminaryReport_Eng.pdf</ref> For hospital births, no family members are allowed to accompany the women into the hospital.<ref>Reed, L. (2007). Midwifery, Freedom to Practice?. Churchill Livingston, Elsevier</ref> For a home birth, a women's mother or sister is often present <ref>Reed, L. (2007). Midwifery, Freedom to Practice?. Churchill Livingston, Elsevier</ref>
===Pain and pain management=== Women in Iraq generally expect that there will be pain with labor and delivery. An absence of pain is often interpreted as a poor progress in labor. Epidurals are not commonly used in public hospitals in Iraq.<ref>Reid, L. (2007). Freedom to Practise?: An International Exploration and Examination of Midwifery Practice. Philadelphia, PA. Elsevier Health Sciences</ref>
===Caesarean rate=== In 2006, 20% of recorded births in Iraq were via [[Caesarean section]].<ref>Iraq: Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2006. (2007). Central Organization for Statistics. Iraq Ministry of Health. Retrieved at http://www.childinfo.org/files/MICS3_Iraq_FinalReport_2006_eng.pdf</ref> The rate was higher in private hospitals and the likelihood increased with a woman's age and education level <ref>Iraq: Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2006. (2007). Central Organization for Statistics. Iraq Ministry of Health. Retrieved at http://www.childinfo.org/files/MICS3_Iraq_FinalReport_2006_eng.pdf</ref>
==Post-birth care== ===Breastfeeding=== A recent report found that only 20% of newborns in Iraq are exclusively fed breast milk for the first six months.<ref>Webster, P. C. (2013). Roots of Iraq's maternal and child health crisis run deep. The Lancet, 381(9870), 891-894.DOI: 10.1016/S0140-6736(13)60658-3</ref> There is often pressures to switch to formula feeding, though this can be unsafe in a country such as Iraq where clean drinking water is not always available.<ref>Webster, P. C. (2013). Roots of Iraq's maternal and child health crisis run deep. The Lancet, 381(9870), 891-894.DOI: 10</ref>
===Female circumcision=== [[Female circumcision]] is controversial in Iraq. While it is not widespread throughout the country, it is still common practice in [[Iraqi Kurdistan]].<ref>Rozhgar A. Saleem MBChB MSc , Nasih Othman MBChB PhD , Fattah H. Fattah MBChB MSc , Luma Hazim BSc MSc & Berivan Adnan MBChB MSc (2013) Female Genital Mutilation in Iraqi Kurdistan: Description and Associated Factors, Women & Health, 53:6, 537-551, DOI: 10.1080/03630242.2013.815681</ref> The decision to perform female circumcision is often made by the mother or grandmother on religious, social, or purity grounds.<ref>Rozhgar A. Saleem MBChB MSc , Nasih Othman MBChB PhD , Fattah H. Fattah MBChB MSc , Luma Hazim BSc MSc & Berivan Adnan MBChB MSc (2013) Female Genital Mutilation in Iraqi Kurdistan: Description and Associated Factors, Women & Health, 53:6, 537-551, DOI: 10.1080/03630242.2013.815681</ref> Negative consequences to the child's health include bleeding, sepsis, shock, psychological disorders, [[obstetrical complications]], and urogenital problems.<ref>Rozhgar A. Saleem MBChB MSc , Nasih Othman MBChB PhD , Fattah H. Fattah MBChB MSc , Luma Hazim BSc MSc & Berivan Adnan MBChB MSc (2013) Female Genital Mutilation in Iraqi Kurdistan: Description and Associated Factors, Women & Health, 53:6, 537-551, DOI: 10.1080/03630242.2013.815681</ref> In 2010 the United Nations released a report that placed the prevalence of female genital mutilation at 78% of women in Kurdistan.<ref>Rozhgar A. Saleem MBChB MSc , Nasih Othman MBChB PhD , Fattah H. Fattah MBChB MSc , Luma Hazim BSc MSc & Berivan Adnan MBChB MSc (2013) Female Genital Mutilation in Iraqi Kurdistan: Description and Associated Factors, Women & Health, 53:6, 537-551, DOI: 10.1080/03630242.2013.815681</ref> A more recent survey of 1,508 women in Kurdistan recorded a prevalence of 23% of women, with the mean age at which it performed being 4.6 years old.<ref>Rozhgar A. Saleem MBChB MSc , Nasih Othman MBChB PhD , Fattah H. Fattah MBChB MSc , Luma Hazim BSc MSc & Berivan Adnan MBChB MSc (2013) Female Genital Mutilation in Iraqi Kurdistan: Description and Associated Factors, Women & Health, 53:6, 537-551, DOI: 10.1080/03630242.2013.815681</ref> Traditionally the procedure is performed at home by a midwife, traditional birth attendant, or relative. In 2011 a law was passed which made female circumcision illegal in Iraqi Kurdistan<ref>Rozhgar A. Saleem MBChB MSc , Nasih Othman MBChB PhD , Fattah H. Fattah MBChB MSc , Luma Hazim BSc MSc & Berivan Adnan MBChB MSc (2013) Female Genital Mutilation in Iraqi Kurdistan: Description and Associated Factors, Women & Health, 53:6, 537-551, DOI: 10.1080/03630242.2013.815681</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
*Al Hilfi, T. K., Lafta, R., & Burnham, G. (2013). Health services in Iraq. The Lancet, 381(9870), 939-948. DOI: 10.1016/S0140-6736(13)60320-7 *Webster, P. C. (2013). Roots of Iraq's maternal and child health crisis run deep. The Lancet, 381(9870), 891-894.DOI: 10.1016/S0140-6736(13)60658-3 *Iraq: WHO Statistical Profile. (January, 2015). Global Health Observatory. Retrieved on March 21st, 2015 at http://www.who.int/gho/countries/irq.pdf?ua=1 *Rozhgar A. Saleem MBChB MSc, Nasih Othman MBChB PhD, Fattah H. Fattah MBChB MSc, Luma Hazim BSc MSc & Berivan Adnan MBChB MSc (2013) Female Genital Mutilation in Iraqi Kurdistan: Description and Associated Factors, Women & Health, 53:6, 537-551, DOI: 10.1080/03630242.2013.815681
