revision.text:
{{expert needed|Genetics|date=August 2008}} {{Infobox disease | Name = Hydrolethalus syndrome | Image = Autosomal recessive - en.svg | Alt = | Caption = Hydrolethalus syndrome is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner | DiseasesDB = 34380 | ICD10 = Q87.8 | ICD9 = | ICDO = | OMIM = 236680 | MedlinePlus = | eMedicineSubj = | eMedicineTopic = | MeshID = | GeneReviewsID = | GeneReviewsName = | Orphanet = 2189 }} '''Hydrolethalus syndrome''' ('''HLS'''), less commonly referred to as '''Salonen-Herva-Norio syndrome''', is a rare [[genetic disorder]] that causes improper [[fetal development]], resulting in [[birth defect]]s and, most commonly, [[stillbirth]].<ref>[http://www.enotes.com/genetic-disorders-encyclopedia/hydrolethalus-syndrome E-Notes: Hydrolethalus Syndrome]</ref>
HLS is associated with [[HYLS1]] mutations. The gene encoding HYLS1 is responsible for proper cilial development within the human body. [[Cilia]] are microscopic projections that allow sensory input and signalling output within cells, as well as cell motility.<ref name="cg11">{{cite journal |vauthors= Oka M, Shimojima K, Yamamoto T, Hanaoka Y, Sato S, Yasuhara T, Yoshinaga H, Kobayashi K | title = A novel HYLS1 homozygous mutation in living siblings with Joubert syndrome | journal = Clinical Genetics | volume = 89 | issue = 6 | pages = 739–43 | date = June 2016 | pmid = 26830932 | doi= 10.1111/cge.12752 }}</ref> Dysfunction results in a range of abnormalities that are often the result of improper cell signalling.<ref name="pn10">{{cite journal |vauthors= Waters A, Beales P | title = Ciliopathies: an expanding disease spectrum | journal = Pediatric Nephrology | volume = 26 | issue = 7 | pages = 1039–56 | date = July 2011 | pmid = 21210154 | pmc = 3098370 | doi= 10.1007/s00467-010-1731-7 }}</ref> A variant form, HLS2, with additional mutations to the ''KIF7'' gene, is less common.<ref name="ng12">{{cite journal |vauthors= Putoux A, Thomas S, Coene K, Davis E, Alanay Y, Ogur G, Uz E, Buzas D, Gomes C, Patrier S, Bennett C, Elkhartoufi N, Frison M, Rigonnot L, Joyé N, Pruvost S, Utine G, Boduroglu K, Nitschke P, Fertitta L, Thauvin-Robinet C, Munnich A, Cormier-Daire V, Hennekam R, Colin E, Akarsu N, Bole-Feysot C, Cagnard N, Schmitt A, Goudin N, Lyonnet S, Encha-Razavi F, Siffroi J, Winey M, Katsanis N, Gonzales M, Vekemans M, Beales P, Attié-Bitach T | title = KIF7 mutations cause fetal hydrolethalus and acrocallosal syndromes | journal = Nature Genetics | volume = 43 | issue = 6 | pages = 601–6 | date = June 2011 | pmid = 21552264 | pmc = 3674836 | doi= 10.1038/ng.826 }}</ref> ''KIF7'' also ensures correct cilia formation and function, specifically cilia stability and length.<ref name="cml9">{{cite journal |vauthors= Takao D, Verhey K | title = Gated entry into the ciliary compartment | journal = Cellular and Molecular Life Sciences | volume = 73 | issue = 1 | pages = 119–27 | date = January 2016 | pmid = 26472341 | pmc = 4959937 | doi= 10.1007/s00018-015-2058-0 }}</ref>
Hydrolethalus syndrome (HLS) was first mistakenly identified in Finland, during a study on [[Meckel syndrome]].<ref name="jomg3">{{cite journal |vauthors=Salonen R, Herva R | title = Hydrolethalus syndrome | journal = Journal of Medical Genetics | volume = 27 | issue = 12 | pages = 756–59 | date = December 1990 | pmid = 2074561 | pmc = 1017280 | doi= 10.1136/jmg.27.12.756 }}</ref> Like HLS, Meckel syndrome presents with severe physiological abnormalities, namely disruptions to the [[central nervous system]] and the presence of extra fingers or toes ([[polydactyly]]).<ref name="jomg3" /> HLS can be distinguished from Meckel syndrome by analysing kidney function, which is dysfunctional in Meckel syndrome as a result of [[cyst]] formation.<ref name="rg4">{{cite journal |vauthors=Honkala H | title = The molecular basis of hydrolethalus syndrome | journal = ResearchGate | pages = 756–59 | date = March 2009 }}</ref>
== Symptoms == HLS presents itself as various, lethal developmental abnormalities, which often result in either premature stillbirth or death shortly after birth.<ref name="jomg3" /> Rare cases of children born with HLS surviving for several months have been noted.<ref name="rg4" /> A characteristic abnormality of HLS is an absence of brain tissue and midline structures, with the presence of excess brain fluid ([[hydrocephalus]]) as a result of abnormal development of the central nervous system.<ref name="jomg3" /> Other common defects include incomplete lung development, heart defects, a [[cleft lip]] or [[cleft palate|palate]], polydactyly, and an abnormally small jaw.<ref name="jomg3" /> Stillbirth and an excess of amniotic fluid ([[polyhydramnios]]) are common during pregnancy with a HLS-affected foetus, with cases of up to 8 litres cited compared to the normal 1 litre.<ref name="rg4" /> Less common symptoms such as abnormally small eyes and a broad nose are also possible.
==Cause==
===Genetic=== HLS is caused by a genetic [[missense mutation]] of the ''HYLS1'' gene, encoding for Hydrolethalus syndrome protein 1, on [[chromosome 11]];<ref name="rg4" /> a single base change to the [[amino acid]] sequence for ''HYLS1'' in [[exon]] 6 involves the replacement of [[aspartic acid]] 211 with [[glycine]] (D211G) in the polypeptide chain.<ref name="pg6">{{cite journal |vauthors= Honkala H, Lahtela J, Fox H, Gentile M, Pakkasjärvi N, Salonen R, Wartiovaara K, Jauhiainen M, Kestilä M | title = Unraveling the disease pathogenesis behind lethal Hydrolethalus syndrome revealed multiple changes in molecular and cellular level | journal = PathoGenetics | volume = 2 | issue = 2 | date = April 2009 | pmid = 19400947 | pmc = 2686686 | doi= 10.1186/1755-8417-2-2 }}</ref> Exon 6 is the only protein coding exon in ''HYLS1''; proper functioning of exons 1-5 ensures regulation and expression of the entire protein.<ref name="rg4" /> HLS is an [[autosomal recessive]] syndrome;<ref name="hmg5">{{cite journal |vauthors= Mee L, Honkala H, Kopra O, Vesa J, Finnilä S, Visapää I, Sang T, Jackson G, Salonen R, Kestilä M, Peltonen L | title = Hydrolethalus syndrome is caused by a missense mutation in a novel gene HYLS1| journal = Human Molecular Genetics | volume = 14 | issue = 11 | pages = 1475–88 | date = April 2005 | pmid = 15843405 | doi= 10.1093/hmg/ddi157 }}</ref> development is only possible if both parents carry the defective gene, and in that instance, the risk of the foetus developing the syndrome is 25%. HLS is a member of the [[Finnish disease heritage]],<ref name="rg4" /> with incidences more common in Finland than the rest of the world; roughly 1 in 20,000 developing foetuses are affected in Finland.<ref name="jomg3" /> Rare cases in other regions have also been documented, often with less severe [[phenotypes]] as a result of [[allele]] variability across countries, allowing survival of affected offspring for up to several months.<ref name="rg4" /> Individuals of Finnish descent are advised to undergo [[genetic testing]] before attempting to conceive.
Prior to the discovery of HLS, the ''HYLS1'' gene was unknown, and similar genes within humans have not been identified.<ref name="rg4" /> [[Orthologs]], genes in other species with common ancestral heritage, have been examined to explain the pathophysiology of HLS; a similar gene within the roundworm, ''[[Caenorhabditis elegans]]'', is responsible for the formation of cilia.<ref name="gd7">{{cite journal |vauthors= Dammermann A, Pemble H, Mitchell B, McLeod I, Yate J, Kintner C, Desai A, Oegema K | title = The Hydrolethalus syndrome protein HYLS-1 links core centriole structure to cilia formation | journal = Genes & Development | volume = 23 | issue = 17 | pages = 2046–59 | date = September 2009 | pmid = 19656802 | pmc = 2751977| doi= 10.1101/gad.1810409 }}</ref> Current hypotheses place a dysfunction of cilia as the main cause of HLS defects arising from the ''HYLS1'' mutation in humans.<ref name="rg4" /><ref name="hmg5" /> Differences between [[wild type]] and mutant ''HYLS1'' have been clearly observed; the wild type form is localised to the [[cytoplasm]], while the mutant form is localised to the [[Cell nucleus|nucleus]] and forms small clusters, suggesting that the mutant gene disrupts cellular localisation.<ref name="hmg5" /> The protein encoded by the ''HYLS1'' mutant form is unable to carry out essential targeting of [[centrioles]] to the plasma membrane, disrupting ciliary function, which results in [[ciliopathy]].<ref name="gd7" /> As cilia are located in almost all cells throughout the body, cilial dysfunction causes developmental defects in a range of organs and thus the phenotype of HLS can vary greatly, though brain malformation and polydactyly are most commonly observed.
===Environmental=== Currently, no [[environmental factors]] are known to increase the likelihood of HLS development or progression; HLS is caused only by [[genetic abnormalities]].<ref name="cml9" />
==Pathophysiology== The [[pathophysiology]] of HLS is abnormal cilia development arising from the inability of the mutated ''HYLS1'' gene to correctly target centrioles to the plasma membrane.<ref name="gd7" /> Specifically, transition fibres within the transition zone, at the base of the [[axoneme]] and adjoining to the plasma membrane, lack proper development.<ref name="nc8">{{cite journal |vauthors= Wei Q, Zhang Y, Schouteden, C, Zhang, Y, Zhang, Q, Dong, J, Wonesch, V, Ling, K, Dammermann, A, Hu, J | title = The hydrolethalus syndrome protein HYLS-1 regulates formation of the ciliary gate | journal = Nature Communications | volume = 7 | issue = 12437 | date = August 2016 | pmid = 27534274 | pmc = 4992140 | doi= 10.1038/ncomms12437}}</ref> As these structures form the cilial gate, improper development results in a loss of selectivity for protein entry into the ciliary compartment.<ref name="cml9" />
==Diagnosis== HLS can be readily diagnosed during pregnancy through the use of [[ultrasound]], which will often reveal [[hydrocephaly]] and an abnormal structure of the brain.<ref name='Orphanet' /> Precise examination via ultrasound or at birth is necessary to rule out Meckel syndrome, [[Trisomy 13]], or [[Smith-Lemli-Opitz syndrome]], which present with similar physiological defects.<ref name="rg4" /> HLS can be detected at the end of the first trimester, approximately 13 weeks [[gestation]].<ref name="pg6" />
==Treatment== No cure or treatment option for individuals with HLS currently exist.<ref name="Orphanet">{{Cite web |url=http://www.orpha.net/consor/cgi-bin/Disease_Search.php?lng=EN&data_id=2075&MISSING%2520CONTENT=Hydrolethalus&search=Disease_Search_Simple&title=Hydrolethalus |title=Orphanet: Hydrolethalus |date=2017-09-10 |language=en |access-date=2017-09-10}}</ref> Due to the severity of the foetal defects and the poor prognosis for those with HLS, the pregnancy is often terminated.<ref name="rg4" /> Certain prevention can only be achieved by avoiding conception if genetic testing indicates both prospective parents as carriers of the defective ''HYLS1'' gene.<ref name="hmg5" />
==Variations and related pathologies== Mutations in ''KIF7'' have also been noted in patients that present a similar phenotype to HLS and the characteristic ''HYLS1'' A to G transformation; [[homozygous]] deletion of the ''KIF7'' gene causes a variant form of HLS, HLS2.<ref name="ng12" /> ''KIF7'' encodes a structural factor vital to cilial transport, and is also implicated in other developmental disorders, such as [[Joubert syndrome]] (JS).<ref name="cg11" /> Additionally, mutations in ''HYLS1'' are no longer explicitly connected to HLS in humans.<ref name="cg11" /> Homozygous mutations removing the stop [[codon]] in exon 4 of ''HYLS1'' result in a different genomic sequence disruption to the missense mutation of HLS, and phenotypically present as JS.<ref name="pn10" /> The ‘molar tooth sign’ of the brain, an anomaly in which cerebellar volume is reduced but cerebellar shape is retained, resembles the molar tooth and is used to identify JS.<ref name="cg11" /> JS presents with mutations in more than 30 genes, whilst the ''HYLS1'' mutation is the sole cause of HLS, but is also present in the HLS2 variant form with the mutated ''KIF7'' gene.<ref name="ng12" />
==See also== •[[HYLS1]]
== References == {{reflist}}

revision.comment: Bot: Change redirected category [[:Category:Joseon Dynasty|Joseon Dynasty]] to [[:Category:Joseon dynasty|Joseon dynasty]]
revision.text:
'''Hyeminseo''' ({{korean|hangul=혜민서|hanja=惠民署|mr=Hyeminsŏ}}) was the medical authority of the [[Joseon Dynasty]] in [[Korea]]. The officers were in charge of the treatment of commoners and medicine.
In 1392, the year of the foundation of Joseon, the organ was established to succeed the Hyemingoguk ({{korean|labels=no|hangul=혜민고국|hanja=惠民庫局}}), the former medical institution of [[Goryeo]]. In 1414, its name became Hyeminguk ({{korean|labels=no|hangul=혜민국|hanja=惠民局}}), and then finally changed to the name Hyeminseo in 1466 under the reign of [[Sejo of Joseon]]. It was abolished in 1882.
The officers were in charge of producing medicines, teaching disciplines, researching [[Korean medicine]]. Generally, four people were put to as the disciplines. Bureaucrats of Hyeminseo were also appointed through the ''[[gwageo]]'' recruitment examination.
Hyeminseo aimed to benefit the people but its coverage was limited to commoners living in Hanyang (now [[Seoul]]). There was another medical authority called Hwalinseo ({{korean|labels=no|hangul={{linktext|pref=:ko|활인서}}|hanja=活人署}}). Collectively, the two were referred to as Yanguisa ({{korean|labels=no|hangul=양의사|hanja=兩醫司|lit="the two medical authorities"}}).
==Notes== * [http://en.starnnews.com/news/index.html?no=148676 Horse Doctor Cho Seung-woo leaves Hyeminseo] * [http://people.aks.ac.kr/front/tabCon/pos/posView.aks?posId=POS_6JOS_2KS_000292 Academy of Korean Studies]

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2014}} {{Use British English|date=November 2017}} '''ISO 45001''' is an [[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]] standard for management systems of [[occupational health and safety]] (OH&S), published in March 2018. The goal of ISO 45001 is the reduction of occupational injuries and diseases.{{Cite web|url=https://www.iso.org/iso-45001-occupational-health-and-safety.html|title=ISO 45001 Occupational health and safety|website=www.iso.org|language=en|access-date=2018-03-13}} The standard is based on [[OHSAS 18001]], conventions and guidelines of the [[International Labour Organization|International Labour Organization]] including [[ILO]] OSH 2001, and national standards.{{cite web |title=ILO OSH 2001 |url=http://www.ilo.org/safework/info/standards-and-instruments/WCMS_107727/lang--en/index.htm |website=www.ilo.org |publisher=ILO |accessdate=25 September 2018}} It includes elements that are additional to BS OHSAS 18001 (see below: ''ISO 45001 changes compared to OHSAS 18001:2007'') which it is replacing over a three-year migration period from 2018 to 2021.{{cite web |title=ISO 45001 |url=https://www.iso.org/iso-45001-occupational-health-and-safety.html |website=www.iso.org |publisher=ISO official website |accessdate=25 September 2018}} ISO 45001 also follows the High Level Structure of other ISO standards like ISO 9001:2015 and ISO 14001:2015 which makes integration of these standards much easier.{{cite book |last1=International Standards Organisation |first1=ISO |title=Information brochure - ISO 45001 |publisher=ISO |location=Geneva |edition=1 |url=https://www.iso.org/publication/PUB100427.html |accessdate=25 September 2018}}{{cite web |title=ISO high level structure explained |url=https://auditortraining.pwc.com.au/new-iso-high-level-structure-mean/ |website=www.auditortraining.pwc.com.au |publisher=PWC (Price waterhouse coopers) |accessdate=25 September 2018}} ==Development== ISO 45001 was proposed at the ISO in October 2013. The committee ISO/PC 283, created in 2013, had direct responsibility for the standardization process.{{Cite web|url=https://www.iso.org/standard/63787.html|title=ISO 45001:2018 - Occupational health and safety management systems -- Requirements with guidance for use|website=www.iso.org|language=en|access-date=2018-03-13}} At least 70 countries contributed to the drafting process.{{Cite news|url=https://www.iso.org/news/ref2272.html|title=ISO 45001 is now published|work=ISO|access-date=2018-03-13|language=en}} Preparation and committee work lasted until December 2015. From 2015 to 2017, a first draft failed to gain sufficient approval from ISO members and was revised in a second draft, which was approved and refined into a final draft. In the final vote the standard garnered 62 votes in favour, nine abstentions and four votes against from France, India, Spain, and Turkey.{{cite web |url=https://www.preventionbtp.fr/Actualites/Toutes-les-actualites/Europe-Monde/La-norme-ISO-45001-publiee-prochainement |title=La norme ISO 45001 publiée prochainement |author= |date=2018-02-26 |publisher=Organisme Professionnel de Prévention du Bâtiment et Travaux Publics |language=French |access-date=2018-05-09}} The standard was published on 12 March 2018. == Certification == ISO 45001 is set to replace [[OHSAS 18001]] over three years following its publication. It uses the management system standard structure guideline [[Annex SL]] to allow for simplified integration with other management system standards, such as [[ISO 9001]] and [[ISO 14001]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.iso.org/news/ref2270.html|title=Let the migration begin|work=ISO|access-date=2018-03-13|language=en}} The [[International Accreditation Forum]] has published requirements for migration from OHSAS 18001 to ISO 45001.{{Cite web|url=http://www.iaf.nu/articles/Mandatory_Documents_/38|title=IAF Publications: Mandatory Documents|last=|first=|date=2018-02-01|website=www.iaf.nu|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-13}} ISO/IEC TS 17021-10:2018 is a technical specification setting out competence requirements for auditing and certification of ISO 45001.{{cite web |url=https://www.iso.org/standard/71102.html |title=ISO/IEC TS 17021-10:2018 |author= |publisher=ISO |access-date=2018-05-09}} == Adoption == ISO 45001 was adopted as a national standard by Albania, Argentina, Austria, Belgium, Brazil, Bulgaria, Chile, Costa Rica, Croatia, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Ireland, Italy, Malaysia, Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Romania, Serbia, Singapore, Slovenia, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey, the United Kingdom, and Uruguay.N-{{Ref label|discuss|1|a}} Adoption as a national standard is under consideration in Australia.{{cite web |url=https://www.standards.org.au/news/iso-45001-occupational-health-and-safety-management-systems-%E2%80%93-requirements-with-guidance-for-use |title=ISO 45001 Occupational health and safety management systems – Requirements with guidance for use |last=McGrath |first=Scott |date=2018-03-12 |publisher=Standards Australia |access-date=2018-03-19}} == ISO 45001 changes compared to OHSAS 18001:2007 == * Context of the organization (Clause 4.1): The organization shall determine internal and external issues that are relevant to its purpose and that affect its ability to achieve the intended outcome(s) of its OH & S management system. * Understanding the needs and expectations of workers and other interested parties (clause 4.2): interested parties are workers, suppliers, subcontractors, clients, regulatory authorities. * Risk and opportunities (Clauses: 6.1.1, 6.1.2.3, 6.1.4): companies are to determine, consider and, where necessary, take action to address any risks or opportunities that may impact (either positively or negatively) the ability of the management system to deliver its intended results, including enhanced health and safety at the workplace. * Leadership and management commitment (Clauses: 5.1) has stronger emphasis on top management to actively engage and take accountability for the effectiveness of the management system. ==Notes==

revision.text:
{{Primarysources|date=December 2007}} The '''Instituto Nacional de Medicina Legal, I.P.''' (National Legal Medicine Institute) is a [[Portugal|Portuguese]] government-owned organization under direct supervision of the Portuguese Ministry of the Justice, which provides [[forensics|forensic science]] services to the [[law enforcement in Portugal|police forces]] and [[Government of Portugal|government]] agencies of Portugal. The national headquarters of the Instituto Nacional de Medicina Legal are in [[Coimbra]]. Its main general branches are located in [[Coimbra]], [[Lisbon]] and [[Porto]], and are linked with the legal medicine departments at the [[University of Coimbra]], [[University of Lisbon]] and [[University of Porto]].
The institute has laboratories throughout the country, and provides scene-of-crime and forensic investigation staff. Its principal functions are to provide forensic pathology and related scientific services, clinical forensic medicine services, teaching and research.
==External links== *[http://www.inml.mj.pt/ Official site]
[[Category:Law enforcement in Portugal]] [[Category:Forensics organizations]] [[Category:Medical and health organisations in Portugal]]

[[Image:isbd colorlogo.png|thumb|upright=1.5|ISBD logo]] The '''International Society for Bipolar Disorders''' ('''ISBD''') is a [[non-profit organization]] based in [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]], where it was founded June 17, 1999.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.isbd.org/about |title=About ISBD - The International Society for Bipolar Disorders |publisher=ISBD |date=1999-06-17 |accessdate=2013-11-10}}</ref> The society focuses on research and education in [[bipolar disorder]]s.<ref>[https://apps.irs.gov/charities/charitable/index.html Internal Revenue Service of the Department of the United States Treasury]</ref>
The society has a membership consisting of [[mental health professional]]s and patients and their family members representing 50 countries. The mission of the society is to advance the treatment of all aspects of bipolar disorder, thereby improving patient outcomes and quality of life, through fostering international collaboration in education and research. The society hosts biennial professional meetings and offers educational programs. The official journal of the society is ''[[Bipolar Disorders (journal)|Bipolar Disorders]]'' and a subscription is included with membership.
== History == The ISBD was founded at the 3rd International Conference on Bipolar Disorder, in [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]] in June 1999 by David J. Kupfer and [[Thomas Detre]] ([[University of Pittsburgh Medical Center]]).<ref>[http://www.isbd.org Official Website of the International Society for Bipolar Disorders]</ref> In September 1999, the official [[peer-reviewed]] society journal, ''Bipolar Disorders'', published its first issue.
The ISBD held its first meeting in [[Sydney, Australia]] in February 2004 with over 400 participants in attendance. The society held its second meeting in August 2006 in [[Edinburgh, Scotland]] with over 600 attendees. {{As of|2013}}, the society has over 800 members in 50 countries with an elected board representing 15 countries. The president is Willem Nolen.
== Educational programs == The society supports the following educational initiatives: *The Psychiatric Trainee Support program offers psychiatric trainees a free two-year membership in the society in order to enhance knowledge of bipolar disorder among this group, narrow the gap between bipolar research and clinical practice, and ultimately to improve diagnosis, treatment and outcomes for patients with bipolar disorder. These supported memberships are open to psychiatric residents, postgraduate students and junior faculty up to the Assistant Professor or equivalent level with less than five years as faculty in their career trajectory. The programs seek to support 70% of trainees from developing countries. *The Samuel Gershon Awards for Junior Investigators, named in honor of [[Samuel Gershon]], past ISBD President and pioneer of early [[lithium]] research, offer four awards for original research submissions. Awards are based on the originality of the content, as well as the significance of the findings reported, and are evaluated by an international scientific panel under the auspices of the ISBD. These awards are open to psychiatric trainees, postgraduate students and junior faculty up to the assistant professor rank from around the world. The awards are presented in conjunction with the society's biennial meeting where the winners present their research in a special session showcasing the work of junior people in the field. *The ISBD Research Fellowship for Junior Investigators provides an opportunity for the recipient to travel to another facility to get training in a particular type of research methodology (i.e. brain imaging, genetics, clinical trials, etc.). The fellowship is intended to cover up to 6 months support for salary, travel, or some combination of these costs as they are incurred in pursuit of additional training. This could take the form of summer programs, participation in smaller prospective studies, or through some other opportunity.
== Conferences == The society organizes biennial meetings that provides updates on topics such as [[epidemiology]], pharmacotherapy, psychotherapies, genetics, neurobiology, imaging research, and bipolar disorder in special populations.
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * {{Official website|http://www.isbd.org}}
[[Category:Organizations established in 1999]] [[Category:Mental health organizations in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Bipolar disorder]] [[Category:International medical and health organizations]]

revision.text:
'''Kumugwe''' (also '''Komokwa''' or '''Goomokwey''') (pronounced "koo-moo-gwee") is a figure in the mythology of [[Pacific Northwest]] peoples. Known as "Copper-Maker", he is the god of the undersea world revered by the [[Kwakwaka'wakw]] and [[Nuxalk]] [[indigenous peoples|indigenous]] nations. He has a house under the sea filled with riches, and his name means "wealthy one". He is sometimes identified as one and the same as Qaniqilak, the spirit of the summer fishing season, and is then regarded as the adversary of [[Tseiqami]] otherwise known as Thunderbird, the guiding spirit of the Winter [[Hamatsa]] Dance season.
Kumugwe is master of the seals. The posts and beams of his house are living sea lions. Sometimes he appears on the surface of the sea, but his head is so big that it looks like an island. He is responsible for the rising and ebbing of the tides, as well as the riches these tides deposit on beaches, and those claimed by the vagaries of sea weather, both material and human lives. One terrific story recounts how he eats human eyes as if they were crab apples. Kumugwe has the power to see into the future, heal the sick and injured, and bestow powers on those whom he favors.
Many heroes went on quests to reach his undersea abode; those who made it were rewarded with riches and spirit magic. His world is guarded by the octopus. Sometimes Kumugwe himself is conceived of in octopus form. Kumugwe would teach the hero who entered his abode the ways of the sea, and give him gifts of blankets, coppers, songs, masks, and regalia. These items of mystical regalia are called [[Tlugwe]] (or Tlokwe) in [[Kwak'wala]].
One of Kumugwe's epithets is "Copper Maker." He has a wife named Tlakwakilayokwa, which means "Born to Be Copper Maker's Woman." She is also sometimes named Kominaga.
Masks of Kumugwe often show him with sea creature attributes, such as rounded fish eyes, and rows of gills at the corners of his mouth, not to mention fins encircling his head, the suction cups of an octopus, fish and aquatic birds which frame or sit upon his head. His most important totemic animals are loons, seals, sea lions, octopuses, orcas, and sculpins.
==References== {{refbegin}} *Dundes, Alan. (2003). [https://books.google.com/books?id=_QPIoIihrKAC&pg=PA55&lpg=PA55&dq=Born+to+Be+Copper+Maker's+Woman&source=bl&ots=qNot9jN_0W&sig=Ugs44uZCOJU2X_elQWGfw2eU48w&hl=en&ei=QuQvSsyAEJ-ctgPU_4y8CA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1#PPA57,M1 ''Parsing Through Customs'']. [[University of Wisconsin]] Press. {{ISBN|0-299-11264-0}}. *Hawthorn, Audrey. (1988). ''Kwakiutl Art.'' [[University of Washington]] Press. {{ISBN|0-88894-612-0}}. {{refend}}
== External links == * http://www.khenkho.com/about_us.asp * http://people.cornellcollege.edu/jmartin/newberry/quikfact.html

{{Infobox body of water | name = Lac de Serre-Ponçon | native_name = Lac de Sèrra Ponçon | native_name_lang = Vivaro-Alpine | other_name = | image = Serre-poncon-warly.jpg | alt = | caption = | image_bathymetry = | alt_bathymetry = | caption_bathymetry = | location = [[Hautes-Alpes]] and [[Alpes-de-Haute-Provence]] | group = | coordinates = {{coord|44|31|N|6|21|E|region:FR_type:waterbody|display=inline,title}} | type = [[reservoir]] | etymology = | part_of = | inflow = [[Durance]], [[Ubaye]] | rivers = | outflow = [[Durance]] | oceans = | catchment = {{convert|3600|km2|abbr=on}} | basin_countries = [[France]] | agency = | designation = | date-built = {{Start date|1955}} | engineer = | date-flooded = <!-- {{Start date|YYYY|MM|DD}} For man-made and other recent bodies of water --> | length = {{convert|20|km|abbr=on}} | width = {{convert|3|km|abbr=on}} | area = {{convert|28|km2|abbr=on}} | depth = | max-depth = {{convert|90|m|abbr=on}} | volume = {{convert|1.272|km3|acre.ft|abbr=on}} | residence_time = 0.5 year | salinity = | shore = | elevation = max. {{convert|780|m|abbr=on}} | temperature_high = | temperature_low = | frozen = | islands = | islands_category = | sections = | trenches = | benches = | cities = | pushpin_map = France Hautes-Alpes#France Alpes-de-Haute-Provence#France#France Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur | pushpin_label_position = | pushpin_map_alt = | pushpin_map_caption = | website = | reference = }}
'''Lake Serre-Ponçon''' ({{lang-fr|Lac de Serre-Ponçon}}; [[Vivaro-Alpine dialect|Vivaro-Alpine]]: ''Lac de Sèrra Ponçon'') is a [[reservoir]] in the [[Departments of France|departments]] of [[Hautes-Alpes]] and [[Alpes-de-Haute-Provence]], [[Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur]] [[Regions of France|region]], in southeast [[France]], one of the largest in [[Western Europe]]. The lake gathers the waters of the [[Durance]] and the [[Ubaye]] rivers, flowing down through the [[Hautes-Alpes]] and the Alpes du Sud to the [[Rhône River]]. The waters are [[dam]]med by the {{lang|fr|Barrage de Serre-Ponçon}}, a {{convert|123|m||adj=on}} high earth core dam.
As well as water control, sixteen [[hydroelectric]] plants use the water (with additional water control supporting), and the lake provides [[irrigation]] to {{convert|1500|km2}} of land.
==History== The lake was created to control water flow after disastrous floods caused severe damage and loss of life in 1843 and 1856. First proposed in 1895, construction started in 1955 and was completed by 1961.
During construction of the lake, approximately {{convert|3000000|m3}} of material was moved. The dam was constructed and the valley slowly became a lake, flooding some villages in the process. This flooding is the subject of [[Jean Giono]]'s movie ''[[Girl and the River]]'' (1958), starring [[Guy Béart]].
According to the official website of the Muséoscope, the "museum of the largest dam in Europe made of compacted soil", Lac de Serre-Ponçon includes a hydroelectric power plant with a 380 [[Megawatt|MW]] generator.<ref name=Muséoscope>{{cite web |url=http://museoscope-du-lac.com/en/presentation-dam-serre-poncon.html |title=The hydroelectric plant of Serre-Ponçon |work=Muséoscope of Serre-Ponçon lake |accessdate=2018-10-19}}</ref> In addition to the power plant on the lake itself, the dam provides the reservoir and overall water management to facilitate an additional 15 hydroelectric plants along the [[Durance]] and [[Verdon (river)|Verdon]] rivers in south-eastern France, with total capacity of 2,000 MW.<ref name=Muséoscope/>
==Geography== Neighboring [[commune in France|communes]]: * [[Embrun, Hautes-Alpes|Embrun]] * [[Savines-le-Lac]] * [[Chorges]]
==Externals links== * [https://www.serre-poncon-locations.fr Local Travel Guide for holidays at Serre-Ponçon]
==References== *[http://www.industrie.gouv.fr/energie/hydro/donnees/serrepo.htm French Department of Industry] * {{commonscat-inline|Lac de Serre-Ponçon}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Lac De Serre Poncon}} [[Category:Lakes of Hautes-Alpes|Serre Poncon]] [[Category:Landforms of Alpes-de-Haute-Provence|Serre Poncon]] [[Category:Reservoirs in France|Serre Poncon]] [[Category:Lakes of Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur]]

{{Infobox protected area | name = Leighton Moss | iucn_category = | iucn_ref = <!-- images --> | photo = Leighton Moss.jpg | photo_caption = [[Greylag geese]] at Leighton Moss <!-- map --> | map = United Kingdom City of Lancaster#Lancashire | map_image = | map_size = | map_caption = Location in the City of Lancaster district##Location in Lancashire | relief = 1 <!-- location --> | location = [[City of Lancaster]], [[Lancashire]], England | nearest_city = | nearest_town = | coordinates = {{coord|54.163|-2.801|display=inline,title}} | coords_ref = <!-- stats --> | length = | length_mi = | length_km = | width = | width_mi = | width_km = | area_ref = | elevation = | elevation_avg = | elevation_min = | elevation_max = | dimensions = | designation = <!-- dates & info --> | authorized = | created = | designated = | established = | named_for = | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | visitation_ref = | governing_body = | administrator = | operator = Royal Society for the Protection of Birds | owner = <!-- website, embedded --> | website = | embedded = }}
'''Leighton Moss RSPB reserve''' is a [[nature reserve]] in [[Lancashire]], England, which has been in the care of the [[Royal Society for the Protection of Birds]] since 1964.<ref>[http://www.wetlands.org/RSIS/_COP9Directory/Directory/3UK026.html UNITED KINGDOM Ramsar Site 323] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130416072925/http://www.wetlands.org/RSIS/_COP9Directory/Directory/3UK026.html |date=2013-04-16 }}</ref> It is situated at [[Silverdale, Lancashire|Silverdale]] near [[Carnforth]], on the edge of [[Morecambe Bay]] and in the [[Arnside and Silverdale Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty]].
Leighton Moss contains the largest area of [[reed bed]]s in north-west England.<ref name="IBA"></ref> The site provides [[habitat (ecology)|habitats]] for many [[species]] of [[wildlife]], including [[Eurasian bittern|bittern]]s and [[red deer]]. As a [[wetland]] of international importance, it was designated a [[Ramsar site]] in 1985. It is a [[Site of Special Scientific Interest]], a [[Special Protection Area]], and an [[Important Bird Area]].<ref name="IBA">{{cite web | url=http://www.birdlife.org/datazone/sitefactsheet.php?id=2505 | title=Important Bird Areas factsheet: Leighton Moss | accessdate=30 December 2012| author=[[BirdLife International]]}}</ref>
The RSPB reserve also protects an area of [[Morecambe Bay]], where a saltmarsh provides a habitat for birds such as [[pied avocet|avocet]]s.<ref name="BBC">{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-lancashire-18857424 | title=Avocets flourish at RSPB Leighton Moss nature reserve | publisher=BBC News | date=2012 | accessdate=2013-04-08}}</ref>
== History == In 1822 the moss came into the possession of Richard Gillow, grandson of the Lancaster furniture manufacturer [[Robert Gillow]]. Using steam technology, Gillow drained the moss for agriculture. Although the soil is of good quality, by 1918 the land was flooded again, as drainage appeared to have become uneconomic. The area was used for duck shooting.
The RSPB initially leased the moss and then purchased it from the [[Leighton Hall, Lancashire|Leighton Hall estate]].
== Facilities == The reserve is entered through the visitor centre (a converted farmhouse) containing a shop and a tea-room. The centre also contains an education room.
There are seven [[Bird hide|observation hide]]s, which were renewed in 2012 with funding from the [[Heritage Lottery Fund]]. One is named after comedian [[Eric Morecambe]].<ref name="Gazette">{{cite web | url=http://www.thewestmorlandgazette.co.uk/news/10014481.Eric_Morecambe_s_daughter_brings_sunshine_to_new_Leighton_Moss_bird_hide/?ref=mmsp | title=Eric Morecambe's daughter brings sunshine to new Leighton Moss bird hide | work=''[[Westmorland Gazette]]'' | date=2012 | accessdate=March 31, 2013}}</ref> There are also nature trails.
== Management issues == The reed beds are managed to prevent them drying out and also to prevent saline intrusion from the coast. Despite such control of [[ecological succession]], the breeding bittern population (measured by "booming" males) has been in decline. This may be related to the reed beds being relatively mature.
In 2015 there was controversy about a plan to cull "excess" numbers of deer, which were blamed for damaging the reeds.<ref name="deer">{{cite web | url=http://www.thewestmorlandgazette.co.uk/news/11757589.Plans_to_cull_red_deer_at_Leighton_Moss_sparks_row_between_RSPB_reserve_and_animal_rights_campaigners/ | title=Plans to cull red deer | work=Westmorland Gazette | accessdate=1 February 2015 | author=Dickinson, Katie}}</ref>
== Media interest == In 2013 Leighton Moss hosted the BBC's ''[[Autumnwatch]]'' programme.<ref name="LG">{{cite news | url=http://www.lancasterguardian.co.uk/news/local/silverdale-s-ancient-aura-of-wilderness-inspires-bbc-s-autumnwatch-1-6121628 | title=Silverdale's "ancient aura of wildness" | work=Lancaster Guardian | date=2013 | accessdate=3 November 2013}}</ref> The programme returned in 2014.<ref name="WG">{{cite web | url=http://www.thewestmorlandgazette.co.uk/news/11486452.BBC_s_Autumnwatch_to_return_to_Leighton_Moss_next_month/ | title=BBC's Autumnwatch | publisher=''Westmorland Gazette'' (www.thewestmorlandgazette.co.uk) | date=September 2014 | accessdate=24 September 2014}}</ref>
== Opening times == The reserve and visitor centre are open daily all year round (except Christmas Day) from 9 am to dusk and the visitor centre from 9.30 am – 5 pm (4.30 pm November–January inclusive). Entrance is free for RSPB members, and half price for those who come by public transport, bicycle or on foot. [[Silverdale railway station]] is just a few minutes' walk away. The reserve is on a proposed cycle way around Morecambe Bay.<ref name="cycle">{{cite web | url=http://www.sustrans.org.uk/news/test-ride-new-cycle-way-around-morecambe-bay-0 | title=Test ride for new cycle way | publisher=Sustrans | date=2014 | accessdate=2 February 2015}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
==Further reading== *{{cite book|last1=Denwood|first1=Andy|title=Leighton Moss: Ice Age to Present Day|date=2014|publisher=Palatine Books|location=Lancaster|isbn=978-1-874181-98-9}}
== External links == {{commons category}} *[http://www.rspb.org.uk/reserves/guide/l/leightonmoss/index.asp RSPB Leighton Moss reserve]
{{City of Lancaster}}

revision.text:
'''Michele Barry''' is Director of the [[Stanford University]] Center for Innovation in Global Health, and in 2018 was awarded the [[Elizabeth Blackwell Medal]] by the [[American Medical Women's Association]].
== Biography == A qualified [[physician]] and Fellow of the [[American College of Physicians]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://profiles.stanford.edu/michele-barry|title=Michele Barry, MD, FACP's Profile {{!}} Stanford Profiles|website=profiles.stanford.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-10-19}}</ref> Barry has been Director of the Center for Innovation in Global Health at Stanford University since 2009,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Vogel|first=Lauren|date=2017|title=Celebrating more women leaders in global health|journal=CMAJ|volume=189|issue=46|pages=E1433–E1434|doi=10.1503/cmaj.109-5520|issn=1488-2329|pmc=5698039|pmid=29158463}}</ref> and is also Senior Associate Dean for Global Health at Stanford''.''<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.womeningh.org/single-post/2017/05/02/Women-Leader-Spotlight-Dr-Michele-Barry-Director-of-the-Center-for-Innovation-in-Global-Health-and-Senior-Associate-Dean-for-Global-Health-at-Stanford-University|title=Women Leader Spotlight: Dr. Michele Barry, Director of the Center for Innovation in Global Health and Senior Associate Dean for Global Health at Stanford University {{!}} womeningh|website=womeningh|language=en|access-date=2018-10-19}}</ref> In 2011 she also became a Fellow of the [[American Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.astmh.org/awards-fellowships-medals/astmh-fellows|title=ASTMH - Fellows of ASTMH (FASTMH)|website=www.astmh.org|access-date=2018-10-19}}</ref> of which she was also a past president.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Barry|first=Michele|date=2003|title=Presidential Address - Diseases without Borders: Globalization's Challenge to the American Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene: A Call for Public Advocacy and Activism|url=http://www.ajtmh.org/docserver/fulltext/14761645/69/1/0690003.pdf?expires=1539956623&id=id&accname=guest&checksum=9CE53F73100DEBEF14D1E59D0C8641AA|journal=American Journal of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene|volume=69|issue=1|pages=3–7|via=}}</ref> She was elected to the [[National Academy of Medicine]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://healthpolicy.fsi.stanford.edu/people/Michele_Barry|title=FSI {{!}} CHP/PCOR - Michele Barry|website=healthpolicy.fsi.stanford.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-10-19}}</ref>
Prior to her appointment at Stanford, Barry was a Professor of medicine at [[Yale University]]<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://medicine.yale.edu/centuryofwomen/distinguishedwomen/116050.profile|title=Michele Barry > 100 Years of Women at YSM {{!}} Yale School of Medicine|website=medicine.yale.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-10-19}}</ref> and had worked at the university for 28 years.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=20 May 2009|title=Global-Health Expert Michele Barry Arrives at Stanford Medical School to Head Up New Initiatives|url=|journal=Biotech Week|volume=|pages=3747|via=}}</ref> She is an advocate for women's rights in the medicine profession,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.globalhealthnow.org/2018-01/michele-barry-need-more-women-leaders-global-health|title=Michele Barry: The Need for More Women Leaders in Global Health|work=Global Health NOW|access-date=2018-10-19|language=en}}</ref> and during her time at Yale, she wrote the first policy for maternity leave in the Department of Medicine.<ref name=":3" /> She created the Women Leaders in Global Health conference in response to the underrepresentation of women in leadership positions in global health.<ref name=":1" />
She is Director of the Yale/Stanford [[Johnson & Johnson]] Global Health Scholars Program,<ref name=":2" /> which sends physicians to low resource settings in overseas countries, to improve health infrastructure.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://medicine.yale.edu/intmed/globalhealthscholars/about/program.aspx|title=Our Program > Global Health Scholars Program {{!}} Internal Medicine {{!}} Yale School of Medicine|website=medicine.yale.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-10-19}}</ref>
Her research interests are in the fields of [[global health]], [[tropical medicine]], and emerging [[Infection|infectious diseases]].<ref name=":2" /> She has written on the potential for [[pandemic]] disease in fragile states and areas of unrest and civil war, published in the journal [[Daedalus (journal)|Daedalus]],<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wise|first=Paul H.|last2=Barry|first2=Michele|date=2017|title=Civil War & the Global Threat of Pandemics|journal=Daedalus|language=en|volume=146|issue=4|pages=71–84|doi=10.1162/daed_a_00460|issn=0011-5266}}</ref> which she sees as an important but underrepresented research area. Her research approach is [[transdisciplinary]], taking into account the local context of global health issues such as infectious disease.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.globalhealthnow.org/2018-01/changing-global-health-paradigm-michele-barry|title=Changing the Global Health Paradigm: Michele Barry|work=Global Health NOW|access-date=2018-10-19|language=en}}</ref> In her work she highlights how areas of global unrest are often centres of emerging disease, and the complexities of the situation and of solutions.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.harvard.edu/gazette/story/2018/09/outbreak-week-at-harvard-opens-with-talk-on-how-diseases-often-spread-unchecked/|title=‘Outbreak Week’ at Harvard opens with talk on how diseases often spread unchecked|date=2018-09-25|work=Harvard Gazette|access-date=2018-10-19|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Awards == In 2018 Barry was awarded the [[Elizabeth Blackwell Medal]], a prize awarded annually by the American Medical Women's Association, to a woman physician for her outstanding contribution to the cause of [[women in medicine]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.amwa-doc.org/doctors/awards-for-physicians/elizabeth-blackwell-2/|title=Elizabeth Blackwell Award|work=American Medical Women's Association|access-date=2018-10-19|language=en-US}}</ref>
In 2010, she received the [[Ben Kean]] Medal, awarded to a clinician or educator for their dedication to clinical tropical medicine.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.astmh.org/awards-fellowships-medals/awards-and-honors/ben-kean-medal|title=ASTMH - Ben Kean Medal|website=www.astmh.org|access-date=2018-10-19}}</ref>
== Personal life == Barry is married to Mark Cullen,<ref name=":4" /> also a doctor, and has two daughters.<ref name=":1" />

'''Ninazu''' in [[Sumerian mythology]] was a god of the underworld, and of healing. He was the son of [[Enlil]] and [[Ninlil]] or, in alternative traditions, of [[Ereshkigal]] and [[Gugalana]], and was the father of [[Ningiszida]]. In the text [[Enki]] and [[Ninhursag]] he was described as the consort of [[Ninsutu]], one of the deities born to relieve the illness of Enki.
Ninazu was the patron deity of the city of [[Eshnunna]] until he was superseded by Tispak. His sanctuaries were the [[É (temple)|E-sikul]] and [[Ekur|E-kurma]]. Unlike his close relative [[Nergal]], he was generally benevolent.

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2017}} [[File:US Navy 080808-N-3271W-046 Rear Adm. James A. Symonds, commander, Navy Region Northwest, visits with a resident of the nursing home care center at Spokane Veterans Administration Hospital.jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|Rear admiral [[James A. Symonds]] talking to a resident of a nursing home in [[Spokane, Washington]], August 2008]] '''Nursing homes''', also known as convalescent homes, are a type of [[residential care]] that provide around-the-clock nursing care for elderly or disabled people.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.caregiverslibrary.org/caregivers-resources/grp-care-facilities/types-of-care-facilities-article.aspx|title=Types of Care Facilities|last=|first=|date=|website=Care givers library|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Twenty-four-hour nursing care is available. Nursing homes will provide short-term rehabilitative stays following a surgery, illness or injury which may require [[physical therapy]], [[occupational therapy]] or [[speech-language therapy]]. Nursing homes offer other services such as planned activities and daily [[housekeeping]] services. Nursing homes may also be referred to as '''convalescent care''', '''skilled nursing''' or a '''long-term facility'''. Nursing homes may offer [[Alzheimer's disease|memory care]] services or have a separate area specified for memory care.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Esposito|first1=Lisa|title=What Nursing Home 'Memory Care' Means|url=http://health.usnews.com/health-news/patient-advice/articles/2016-06-01/what-nursing-home-memory-care-means|accessdate=29 July 2017|agency=U.S. News & World Report|date=1 June 2016}}</ref>
==History== [[File:Unit visits Nursing Home (23444741899).jpg|thumb]] [[File:Workroom at St James Workhouse.jpg|right|300px|thumb|[[Poorhouse]]s/[[workhouse]]s were the first implemented national framework to provide a basic level of care to the old and infirm. Pictured, is "The workroom at St James's workhouse" from ''The Microcosm of London'' (1808).]] Starting in the 17th century, the concept of [[poorhouse]]s (also referred to as [[almshouse]]s) were brought to America by English settlers. All orphans, mentally ill and the poor elderly were placed into these living commons. These poorhouses gave a place where they could be given shelter and daily meals. Poorhouses continued to exist into the early 20th century despite the criticism they faced. Much of the criticism stemmed from the conditions of the poorhouses. [[Great Depression|The Great Depression]] overwhelmed the poorhouses as there were a lot of people that needed help and care but not enough space and funding in the poorhouses. Due to [[Muckraker|Muck Raking]] in the 1930s the less than favorable living conditions of the poorhouses were exposed to the public.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Watson|first=Sidney D.|date=|title=From Almshouses to Nursing Homes and community care: Lessons from Medicaid History|url=http://readingroom.law.gsu.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=2416&context=gsulr|journal=Georgia State University Law Review|volume=26|pages=|via=}}</ref> Poorhouses were then replaced with a different type of residential living for the elderly. These new residential living homes were called board-and-care homes or also known as [[Convalescent Home|convalescent homes]]. These board-and-care homes would provide basic levels of care and meals in a private setting for a specific fee. Board-and-care homes proved to be a success and by [[World War II|World War 2]], the new way of nursing homes began to take shape. As the times continued to change, the government identified the issue of people spending extensive amounts of time in hospitals. To combat these long stays in short-term settings, board-and-care homes began to convert into something more public and permanent that was state and federally funded. From this, by 1965 nursing homes were a solid fixture. Nursing homes were a permanent residence where the [[elderly]] and [[Disability|disabled]] (poor elderly and disabled specifically) could receive any necessary [[medical care]] and receive daily meals. Though nursing homes in the beginning were not perfect, they were a huge step above almshouses and poorhouses in regards to following laws and maintaining cleanliness. From the 1950s through the 1970s the dynamics of nursing homes began changing significantly. [[Medicare (United States)|Medicare]] and [[Medicaid]] began to make up much of the money that would filter through the homes and the 1965 amendment laws enforced nursing homes to comply with safety codes and required [[registered nurse]]s to be on hand at all times. Later in 1987, the Nursing Reform Act was introduced to begin defining the different types of nursing home services and later added the Residents' Bill of Rights.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.senioradvisor.com/blog/2015/05/history-of-nursing-homes/|title=History of Nursing Homes|last=|first=|date=|website=SeniorAdvisor.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Today nursing homes are very different across the board. Some nursing homes still resemble a hospital while others look more like a home. Nursing home residents can pay for their care out of pocket, others may receive [[Medicare (United States)|medicare]] for a short time and some may use long-term [[insurance]] plans. Across the spectrum, most nursing homes will accept medicaid as a source of payment.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.medicare.gov/what-medicare-covers/part-a/paying-for-nursing-home-care.html|title=Paying for Nursing Home Care|last=|first=|date=|website=Medicare.gov|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
==Staff== In most jurisdictions, nursing homes are required to provide enough staff to adequately care for residents. In the U.S., for instance, nursing homes must have at least one [[registered nurse]] RN available for at least 8 straight hours a day throughout the week, and at least one [[licensed practical nurse]] on duty 24 hours a day.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skillednursingfacilities.org/|title=nursing home staff|publisher=skillednursingfacilities.org|accessdate=12 October 2012}}</ref>
=== Nurses === [[File:The Trained nurse and hospital review (1888) (14761734434).jpg|thumb]] Nursing homes require that an RN be present to assess residents and to monitor their outcomes. The RN's job duties include implementing care plans, administering medications, recording and maintaining accurate reports for each resident, monitoring and recording medical changes and providing direction to the nursing assistant and licensed practical nurses or licensed vocational nurses.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nursingworld.org/EspeciallyForYou/What-is-Nursing/Tools-You-Need/RNsAPNs.html|title=What Nurses Do|last=|first=|date=|website=American Nurses Association|archive-url=|archivedate=|dead-url=|accessdate=}}</ref> To be allowed to work as a Registered Nurse, one must complete a nursing program at one of several educational levels, including associate and bachelor degree programs, hospital-based diploma programs and master's degree programs. Licensed practical nurses complete a state-approved one-year program.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.practicalnursing.org/guides|title=How To Become an LPN/LPN|last=|first=|date=|website=PracticalNursing.org|archive-url=|archivedate=|dead-url=|accessdate=}}</ref> Both registered nurses and licensed practical nurses must pass a national licensing exam before they can begin working. The LPN or LVN monitors residents’ well-being and administers treatments and medications, such as dressing wounds and dispensing prescribed drugs as directed by the Registered Nurse. 
=== Nursing assistants === [[File:Nurse takes a patient's blood pressure.jpg|thumb]] A nursing assistant provides basic care to patients while working directly under an LPN/LVN or RN. These basic care activities, also referred to as activities of daily living, can include assisting with bathing and dressing residents, helping residents with meals, either serving them or with feeding, transferring to and from the bed or wheelchair, making and cleaning beds, assisting with toileting, and answering call lights.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.allnursingschools.com/certified-nursing-assistant/job-description/|title=What You'll Do As A CNA|last=|first=|date=|website=AllNursingSchools.com|archive-url=|archivedate=|dead-url=|accessdate=}}</ref> Training to become a nursing assistant is offered at some high schools, as well as at [[vocational-technical school]]s, community colleges, and nursing homes.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://everynurse.org/becoming-a-cna/|title=How to Become a CNA|last=|first=|date=|website=EveryNurse.org|archive-url=|archivedate=|dead-url=|accessdate=}}</ref> These programs are typically three months to one year in length depending on the program. Nursing assistants are then listed on the state healthcare registry. Nursing assistants' titles can range from facility to facility, the job titles include Certified Nursing Assistants (CNA's), nursing aides, caregivers, patient care associates, patient care techs and care assistants
===Administration=== Depending on the size of the nursing home, a nursing home may have either a nursing home administrator or an [[executive director]]. Some nursing homes may have both but their job duties are similar and can include overseeing staff, supplying medical supplies and financial matters. The nursing home administrators/ executive director's career requires at least a [[bachelor's degree]] and some advanced positions may require a [[Master's degree|master’s degree]]. There are certain classes that are commonly taken in this path of study, these classes include nursing home administrative practices, [[Ageing|aging]] and long term care, [[gerontology]] and aging, and health behavior.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://study.com/articles/Nursing_Home_Administrator_Job_Description_and_Info_for_Students_Considering_a_Career_in_Nursing_Home_Administration.html|title=Nursing Home Administrator|last=|first=|date=|website=Study.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> You may also find human resources employees in a nursing home. This job requires at least a bachelor's degree and usually preferred related work experience. These employees are in charge of all aspects of hiring new employees. Human resources job duties vary but can also include coordinating payroll, organizing orientation programs for new employees, interviewing, disciplinary actions, and ensuring compliance with federal and state laws.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mshealthcareers.com/careers/humanresources.htm|title=Human Resources|last=|first=|date=|website=HealthCareers.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Nursing homes are usually licensed and heavily regulated under governing legislation. Compliance with the federal and state legislatures are reviewed regularly for adherence to strict standards of building codes, care plans, behavior and altercations between residents, nutrition and dietary services, medical services, nursing and personal care, religious and spiritual practices, pets, and recreational programs.<ref>http://www.health.gov.on.ca/en/public/programs/ltc/docs/ltcha_guide_phase1.pdf
A Guide to the Long-Term Care Homes Act, 2007 and Regulation 79/10 </ref>
=== Housekeeping === [[File:Good housekeeping 1908 08 a.jpg|thumb]] Housekeepers are an important part of up keeping nursing homes. [[Housekeeper (domestic worker)|Housekeepers]] play a huge part in ensuring that nursing homes are kept clean and free of [[Disease|disease causing agents]]. Housekeepers have a long list of duties which include cleaning floors, changing linens, disinfecting bathrooms, changing towels, washing clothes, emptying garbage cans, sanitizing rooms, replenishing supplies, dusting and polishing furniture, vacuuming, and keeping windows and woodwork clean. These duties can be  different from facility to facility but will overall include basic [[cleaning]]. Housekeeping does not require any licensure or schooling, but some housekeeping jobs may prefer prior job experience.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://work.chron.com/job-description-senior-living-housekeeper-30677.html|title=Job Description of Senior Living Housekeeper|last=|first=|date=|website=Work.Chron.Com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
=== Recreational staff === Recreational staff usually include an activity director and possibly activity assistants depending on the size of the nursing home. The activity director job requires an [[associate degree]] or a [[bachelor's degree]] and allows for further [[certification]]s through the National Council for Therapeutic Recreation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://study.com/articles/Geriatric_Activities_Director_Job_Description_Duties_and_Requirements.html|title=Geriatric Activities Director Job Description|last=|first=|date=|website=Study.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Activities are planned that aim to meet each residents [[emotion]]al, intellectual, physical, social, spiritual, and vocational needs. The transition from being independent to having to depend on others and be away from home is oftentimes very difficult, which is why activities are important to combat [[Depression (mood)|depression]] and [[anxiety]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mcknights.com/guest-columns/importance-of-being-social-in-a-nursing-home/article/358058/|title=Importance of Being Social in a Nursing Home|last=Petrea, RN|first=Jennifer|date=|website=McKnights|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Some of the different activities that may be offered include hosting birthday parties, celebrating [[holiday]]s, book clubs, musical events, [[Outdoor recreation|outdoor activities]], discussion and social groups, [[Physical exercise|exercise]], arts and crafts, [[Animal-assisted therapy|pet therapy]], religious services and community outings. [[Volunteering|Volunteer]] involvement is also an important part of nursing home activities given that volunteers can act as a link between the nursing home and the outside community.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.theactivitydirectorsoffice.com/ActivitiesDefined.html|title=Activities Defined|last=|first=|date=|website=TheActivityDirectorsOffice.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Therapy == ===Occupational therapy=== One of the many services offered in a nursing home is [[occupational therapy]]. Occupational therapy may be necessary following an injury or illness in order to regain skills and to receive support during any physical or cognitive changes.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.aota.org/About-Occupational-Therapy.aspx|title=About Occupational Therapy|last=|first=|date=|website=AOTA.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Occupational therapy will focus on activities of daily living such as [[bathing]], dressing, [[Personal grooming|grooming]]. Occupational therapy also assists with instrumental activities of daily living which include home and [[financial management]], rest and sleep, [[education]], work, play, [[leisure]], and social participation. Occupational therapists work to allow the person to safely and comfortably reintegrate into society by practicing public dining, transferring to different surfaces (chairs, beds, couches etc.), and will assess the need for any home modifications or safety equipment to ensure a proper and safe transition. When a cognitive and/or perceptual deficit is presented, therapists will work with the person by teaching strategies to maximize memory, sequencing and attention span length. <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.aota.org/~/media/Corporate/Files/AboutOT/Professionals/WhatIsOT/RDP/Facts/FactSheet_SkilledNursingFacilities.pdf|title=Occupational Therapy's Role in Skilled Nursing Facility's|last=|first=|date=|website=AOTA.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
===Physical therapy=== [[File:Student nurses must be versed in occupational therapy 8b08195v.jpg|thumb]] Another important service found in a nursing home is [[physical therapy]]. Physical therapy may be necessary following an injury, illness or surgery. Physical therapy works with the person to help them regain strength, [[endurance]], [[Flexibility (anatomy)|flexibility]], balance and [[range of motion]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://baystatept.com/news/how-do-i-know-if-i-should-see-physical-therapist|title=How Do I Know if I Should See a Physical Therapist|last=|first=|date=|website=BayStatePT.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Physical therapy is also used as a way of preventing [[Injury|injuries]] and accidents by focusing on restoring mobility, increasing fitness levels, reducing pain and overall reaching a certain point of independence. There are many conditions that can benefit from receiving physical therapy in a nursing home, these conditions include [[arthritis]], pain associated with [[cancer]], [[dementia]], [[Alzheimer's disease|Alzheimer's]], [[stroke]] and [[Overactive bladder|incontinence]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ling|first1=Shari M.|title=Rehabilitation of Older Adult Patients with Arthritis|url=https://www.hopkinsarthritis.org/patient-corner/disease-management/rehabilitation-of-older-adult-patients-with-arthritis/|website=Johns Hopkins Arthritis Center|accessdate=29 July 2017|date=13 October 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Physical Therapy|url=http://www.uhhospitals.org/stjohn/services/rehabilitation-services/physical-therapy|website=University Hospitals|publisher=St. John Medical Center|accessdate=29 July 2017}}</ref>
=== Speech language therapy === [[File:Langley therapy dog.jpg|thumb]] [[Speech-language pathology]] is another service found in a nursing home. Speech language [[List of pathologists|pathologists]] specialize in working with those who have a difficult time with language and/or speech, usually following an injury or an underlying [[Diagnosis|diagnoses]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.speechpathology.com/articles/speech-language-pathology-in-long-1446|title=Speech Language Pathology in Long Term Care|last=|first=|date=|website=SpeechPathology.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> The SLP will evaluate the persons [[speech]]. If the person is having trouble with speech, this points to an issue with coordinating the movements and muscles used to produce speech. While trouble with language points to the person having difficulty with understanding what they are hearing and seeing. The SLP will also look at difficulty with [[swallowing]] food and will evaluate the person in order to figure out which part of the swallowing process is not working. Some of the many speech disorders worked with by the SLP are; [[Phonology]] meaning the speech patterns used, [[Apraxia]] meaning difficulty with coordinating the movements needed to make sounds, [[Language processing in the brain|Receptive Language]] meaning difficulty understanding language, Fluency meaning [[stuttering]], [[Expressive language|Expressive Language]] meaning difficulty using language and many other disorders. <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.superduperinc.com/handouts/pdf/162%20SLPs.pdf|title=What is a Speech Language Pathologist?|last=|first=|date=|website=superduperinc.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
==By country==
===Canada=== {{main|Nursing home care in Canada}} [[Long-term care]] facilities exist under three major types: privately owned, non-profit/charitable, and municipal. Regardless of their ownership, aspects of funding, admission criteria, and cost to the individuals are all regulated by their respective provincial governments.<ref>http://www.oltca.com/OLTCA/Documents/Reports/TILTC2016.pdf
This is Long Term Care 2016</ref> As medical care is publicly funded in Canada, all long-term care facilities receive funding from provincial governments for the health care component of the residence – the nurses and personal support workers. Residents pay daily rates for 'room and board' (accommodation and food) that are determined by the type of room chosen, either shared or private. Provincial governments manage waiting lists for long-term care facilities. People who cannot afford to pay the monthly fees receive subsidies, and no one is refused due to inability to pay.<ref>https://www.ontario.ca/page/find-long-term-care-home
Find a long-term care home </ref>
===United Kingdom=== {{Main|Nursing home care in the United Kingdom}} In the [[United Kingdom]], care homes and care homes with nursing are regulated by different organisations in [[England]], [[Scotland]], [[Wales]] and [[Northern Ireland]]. To enter a care home, a candidate patient needs an assessment of needs and of their financial condition from their local council. The candidate may also have an assessment by a [[nurse]], should the patient require nursing care. The cost of a care home is [[means tested]] in England.
Care homes for adults in England are regulated by [[Care Quality Commission]], which replaced the [[Commission for Social Care Inspection]], and each care home is inspected at least every three years. In Wales the Care Standards Inspectorate for Wales has responsibility for oversight, In Scotland [[Social Care and Social Work Improvement Scotland]] otherwise known as the Care Inspectorate, and in Northern Ireland the Regulation and Quality Improvement Authority in Northern Ireland.
In 2002, nursing homes became known as care homes with nursing, and residential homes became known as care homes.<ref name=":0">{{cite web |title=NHS Continuing Healthcare, NHS funded healthcare and intermediate care,|publisher= Age Concern |date= August 2007|url= http://www.ipbh.org.uk/healthsocialcare/documents/NHScontinuinghealthcareNHS-fundednursingcareandintermediatecare.pdf}}</ref>
As of April 2009 in England, the lower capital limit is £13,500. At this level, all income from [[pension]]s, savings, benefits and other sources, except a "personal expenses allowance" (currently £21.90), goes towards paying the care home fees. The [[Local government in the United Kingdom|local council]] pays the remaining contribution provided the room occupied is not more expensive than the local council's normal rate.<ref>{{cite web|last=Compare Care Homes Advice|title=‘Funding a Care Home’ – a comprehensive financial guidance leaflet from Comparecarehomes.com.|url=http://www.comparecarehomes.com/images/CCH-finance%20detailed.pdf|format=PDF|accessdate=1 March 2010}}</ref> The NHS has full responsibility for funding the whole placement if the resident is in a care home with nursing that meets the criteria for NHS continuing Health Care. This is identified by a multidisciplinary assessment process.<ref>as detailed on the [[Department of Health (United Kingdom)|Department of Health]] website</ref><!---probably should expand to real citation-->
In May 2010, the Coalition Government announced the formation of an [[Andrew Dilnot#Dilnot Commission|independent commission on the funding of long-term care]], which was due to report within a 12-month time frame on the financing of care for an [[Ageing population]]. It delivered its recommendations on Monday 4 July 2011. The [[Care Quality Commission]] have themselves implemented a re-registration process, completed in October 2010, which will result in a new form of regulation being outlined in April 2011.<ref>{{cite web |title=Dilnot Commission on Funding of Care and Support |publisher=Age UK |url=http://www.ageuk.org.uk/home-and-care/dilnot-commission-on-funding-of-care-and-support |accessdate=28 April 2013 }}</ref>
===United States=== {{main|Nursing home care in the United States}} In the United States, there are three main types of nursing facilities (NFs).
An intermediate care facility (ICF) is a health care facility for individuals who are disabled, elderly, or non-acutely ill, usually providing less intensive care than that offered at a hospital or skilled nursing facility. Typically an ICF is privately paid by the individual or by the individual's family. An individual's private health insurance and/or a third party service like a [[hospice]] company may cover the cost. '''Board and Care Homes''' are special facilities designed to provide those who require assisted living services both living quarters and proper care. Often referred to as residential care homes, these facilities can either be located in a small residential home or a large modern facility. In fact, a large majority of board and care homes are designed to room less than 6 people. Board and care homes are typically staffed by licensed professionals, including nurses, doctors and other medical professionals. These facilities are highly regulated in order to ensure that the best possible care is being provided for the residents. Board and care homes offer residents 24 hour assistance, making them a highly popular choice for those in need of regular assistance.
[[Assisted living residences]] or [[assisted living facilities]] (ALFs) are housing facilities for people with [[disabilities]]. These facilities provide supervision or assistance with [[activities of daily living]] (ADLs); ALFs are an eldercare alternative on the continuum of care for people, for whom independent living is not appropriate but who do not need the 24-hour medical care provided by a nursing home and are too young to live in a retirement home. Assisted living is a philosophy of care and services promoting independence and dignity.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fullcirclecare.org/ltcontinuum/nursing.html |title=ltcontinuum |publisher=fullcirclecare.org |date= |accessdate=12 October 2012}}</ref>
A skilled nursing facility (SNF) is a nursing home certified to participate in, and be reimbursed by [[Medicare (United States)|Medicare]]. Medicare is the federal program primarily for the aged (65+) who contributed to Social Security and Medicare while they were employed. [[Medicaid]] is the federal program implemented with each state to provide health care and related services to those who are below the poverty line. Each state defines poverty and, therefore, Medicaid eligibility. Those eligible for Medicaid may be low-income parents, children, including [[State Children's Health Insurance Program]]s (SCHIPs) and maternal-child wellness and food programs.{{Citation needed|date=June 2012}} seniors, and people with disabilities.
The [[Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services]] is the component of the [[U.S. Department of Health and Human Services]] (DHHS) that oversees Medicare and Medicaid. A large portion of Medicare and Medicaid dollars is used each year to cover nursing home care and services for the elderly and disabled. State governments oversee the licensing of nursing homes. In addition, states have a contract with CMS to monitor those nursing homes that want to be eligible to provide care to Medicare and Medicaid beneficiaries. Congress established minimum requirements for nursing homes that want to provide services under Medicare and Medicaid. These requirements are broadly outlined in the Social Security Act, which also entrusts the Secretary of Health and Human Services with the responsibility of monitoring and enforcing these requirements. CMS is also charged with the responsibility of working out the details of the law and how it will be implemented, which it does by writing regulations and manuals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.medicare.gov/|title=Nursing Home Inspections|publisher=medicare.gov|accessdate=12 October 2012}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Health|Housing}} {{col div|colwidth=30em}} *[[Care Quality Commission]] previously known as [[Commission for Social Care Inspection]] *[[Certified Medical Director]] *[[Eldercare]] *[[Home care]] *[[IAHSA|International Association for Homes and Services for the Aging]] * [[LGBT ageing]] *[[List of companies operating nursing homes]] *[[Retirement village]] {{colend}}
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Commons category|Nursing homes}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Nursing Home}} [[Category:Caregiving]] [[Category:Nursing homes| Nursing home]] [[Category:Types of healthcare facilities]]
